author: {'steamid': '76561198275934366', 'num_games_owned': 812, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 93, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 93, 'last_played': 1705266683}
review:
It introduces some genuinely interesting ideas in each level but its main flaws are the janky, unintuitive in game physics and the unclear hitboxes of enemy attacks which lead to imprecise, frustrating platforming and annoying bosses, especially against [your evil version].
The main weapon of the game is horrendously inflexible and doesnt allow for precise or fast platforming, there is seemingly no momentum or power behind the lasers.

Also the humorous premise wears out, quickly.
Very quickly.

+ Simple and nice game graphics/design
+ Replayable game
+ Fast-paced game
+ Fun to play

- Difficult controls
- Kinda expensive for a game that was originally a browser game that is free to play a long time ago

review: Revisited this because i wasn't sure why i never finished it. I immediately realised. Horrible audio quality, low resolution with no setting to change it, extreme screen shake almost always, almost no useful settings in the options menu, and getting adjusted to the controls is just very clumsy feeling. I love the concept and the humour, but this is a pretty damn low quality game. The humour is overdone to the point of being annoying, and while the game itself seems like it would be fun, it's such poor quality that I didn't find myself actually getting much enjoyment out of it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198089693705', 'num_games_owned': 760, 'num_reviews': 169, 'playtime_forever': 464, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 464, 'last_played': 1692748385}
review:
No Time to Explain Remastered is a platformer where you play as a dude who sees his future self being absolutely dominated by some giant crab thing and is given a powerful laser cannon to try and save his future self. 

The story is pretty easy to ignore. It's very disconnected and is only loosely connected by a theme around multiple dimensions. It isn't bad, but considering that this originates from a flash game that wasn't focused on having a fleshed-out story, it's to be expected. But that likely isn't what most people are playing this game for. 

The gameplay is obviously one of the shining stars of the game, and it doesn't disappoint. It may not be full of many features that newer games boast, but it uses a simple concept well. You have a powerful laser cannon to propel yourself and destroy things. That's all this game needs. However, even with that being good enough, the game also features different guns that you can use to propel yourself, such as a shotgun laser blaster thingy or literal telekinesis. The map design is also quite nice, as the puzzles are never too difficult, but they aren't mind-numbingly easy. It's the perfect amount of difficulty for a game like this. The maps also follow in suit of the variety that the guns have, as some maps include completely new mechanics that are fun to engage with, such as catching yourself on fire to burn down wooden blockades but making sure you douse yourself in water before you die. 

The graphics have that clean Flash game look, so I can't complain there. It doesn't stand out, but it also doesn't disappoint. The sound design is also fairly solid, as basically all cutscenes are fully voiced, as well as various comedic remarks from your future self who is getting maimed. Even when the jokes aren't funny, they don't overstay their welcome. The music is also pretty nice.

Overall, I think this game has a lot going for it in such a simple package. It knows what it is trying to be and does it well. It's also pretty funny with the various scenarios the game puts you in, and it truly oozes that old "Flash game charm." It's one of those games that you can complete in a single session during an afternoon after work or in a few hours on a weekend. I recommend giving this game a try, but only maybe when it goes on sale ;)

author: {'steamid': '76561198044138266', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 145, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 145, 'last_played': 1655161275}
review: This game is definitely not worth 15 bucks. If you want to laugh and enjoy the art style or play a similar game - there's multitudes on newgrounds if you want to hit that nostalgia button. This game doesn't offer anything special or enticing enough to justify the price point whatsoever. Surprised at the amount of positive reviews it has. Just make sure you REALLY want the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198101064176', 'num_games_owned': 993, 'num_reviews': 197, 'playtime_forever': 327, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 327, 'last_played': 1617125158}
review:
No Time to Explain Remastered is a fast-paced action game developed by tinyBuild. The game features a quirky and humorous story, fast-paced gameplay, and challenging levels that will keep players on their toes.

The game's story begins with the player character, who is suddenly attacked by a giant crab-like creature, causing him to lose his trusty jetpack. Determined to get it back, the player sets out on a wild and crazy adventure through time and space, battling a variety of enemies and obstacles along the way.

One of the standout features of No Time to Explain Remastered is its humor. The game's story is full of hilarious moments and quirky characters that will keep players entertained throughout the game. The game's graphics and animations are also well-done, with a colorful and cartoony art style that perfectly matches the game's lighthearted tone.

The game's gameplay is fast-paced and challenging, with a variety of weapons and upgrades to unlock as players progress through the game. Players must navigate through a series of increasingly difficult levels, using their wits and reflexes to avoid traps and defeat enemies. The game's controls are tight and responsive, making it easy to pull off tricky maneuvers and acrobatic stunts.

The game's soundtrack is also well-done, with a mix of upbeat and energetic tracks that perfectly match the game's action-packed gameplay. The game's sound effects are also impressive, with a variety of satisfying explosions and zany sound effects that add to the game's overall charm.

Overall, No Time to Explain Remastered is a fun and entertaining game that's well worth playing. Its humor, fast-paced gameplay, and challenging levels make it a standout game that's sure to please fans of action games. If you're looking for a game that's full of laughs and adrenaline-pumping action, No Time to Explain Remastered is definitely worth checking out.

review: I recommend giving it a shot if you like indie games and don't mind unique platforming mechanics and like a challenge. The developer does a really good job of not telling you exactly what to do, but making it obvious with good visual ques. Well not always obvious, some things have puzzle elements that take some figuring out. Overall I really like it so far and find the difficulty engaging but not oppressively punishing.

author: {'steamid': '76561198082764480', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 428, 'playtime_forever': 118, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 118, 'last_played': 1675959484}
review:
No Time To Explain is a platformer that plays completely differently than others in the genre. You start with a laser beam that you can use to boost yourself up or hit enemies. The weapons and mechanics change throughout the game and since the game takes around 2 hours to fully complete, it never gets stale.
The game is basically a great representation of 2010's flash games. It has a great mechanic, it builds upon said mechanics and doesn't drag on for too long.
If you are searching for something fresh, i really suggest you to try this game however, i think even though it has workshop support,the game is too expensive for how short it is . I recommend getting it on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561197994336777', 'num_games_owned': 1764, 'num_reviews': 95, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1674419551}
review:
This game is a classic, and the remaster just makes it slicker and couch co-op friendly.
I love playing this game with my kids. It's hard, but fair, and any 1 player can carry the group on each map.  It can be a little difficult to share the screen when someone gets left behind or someone blazes ahead, but having to time things and cooperate is half the fun.

I'd be remiss if I didn't mention the EXCELLENT dialog. The voice actor must have had a riot reading all those lines!

author: {'steamid': '76561198013073925', 'num_games_owned': 905, 'num_reviews': 198, 'playtime_forever': 194, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 175, 'last_played': 1674160983}
review:
[b] Disclaimer:[/b] I received this game as a gift.

This is one of the flash games era platformers that survived and even got an enhanced version as the years went on. 
The story doesn't take itself too seriously ("I Am You From The Future! No Time To Explain, Follow m-OH CHRIST!" for about 7 times until you meet 7 versions of yourself from different timelines that have to beat the villain), however the mechanics are interesting enough and change from level to level. 
I first tried playing with an Xbone controller but the controls were atrocious (with no way of changing them in any meaningful manner) so I switched to KB+M and it was fine. There are some frustrating platforming segments (I don't really like the water torrent weapon for moving around and sadly that's what we have to use for the most part), by far the boss fights were the most fun for me.
I don't really see why the 15 euro price tag is a thing, as this is an old game that can be finished in about 2 hours depending on the player. 

[b] Worth buying? [/b] If the gameplay looks like your cup of tea or you're nostalgic for the flash game era then yes, but I recommend waiting for a sale or getting it in a bundle. If you already have it I recommend at least trying it once.

author: {'steamid': '76561198155145382', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 252, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 252, 'last_played': 1668325425}
review:
Recommended as a on sale pick up game since its not very long.

Overall I would say the game isn't very hard considering that I didnt know until after a couple of levels with the shotgun that you could move without the gun and that using the directional keys made you go farther and higher. I would say that the game is frustrating but rewarding which is what you want from a 2d platformer of this style. There are other levels made by people if you want to try them but I would say that the best parts of the game are unfortunately the shortest. Its not a $15 game but its not bad for 5

author: {'steamid': '76561198026806776', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 302, 'playtime_forever': 76, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 76, 'last_played': 1667006870}
review:
[i]No Time to Explain[/i] is among the earliest and most notable examples of the "deliberately hard to control meme-game," a metagenre that also includes games like [i]QWOP[/i] and [i]Surgeon Simulator[/i]. The fun in games like these does not come from success at challenges, but from the way it pushes you into repeated comical failures.

The context in which you play such games is critical. If you're playing in a room with a few friends, all taking turns to die horribly and laugh at each others' failures, it's great! The same can be true with Twitch streaming, or even the "Let's Play" video format. All these scenarios hinge on your willingness to be the butt of the joke, which can be a lot of fun, with the right people.

But if you're playing [i]No Time to Explain[/i] alone, nobody watching, nobody laughing along with you, expecting the typical video-game difficulty curve where you gradually master a game to overcome increasingly greater challenges, you will be frustrated. The intentionally-bad-control metagenre demands that you develop skill, yes, but is also heavily dependent on a "try until you get lucky" mechanic. You will fail each challenge several times, then finally succeed... but should you return to that challenge, you will likely fail as many times as you did before, because success in these games hinges not on skill alone, but (skill factor + fluke chance)*repeated attempts. 

If you're not playing in a context that's in some way social, then pass right by [i]No Time to Explain[/i]. Watch somebody's stream or video of them playing it instead. Laugh at them. That's what this game is for.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000998015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1537, 'playtime_forever': 569, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 569, 'last_played': 1512222569}
review:
Simple gameplay? Check.
Cool art style? Check.
Replayable? Check.
Silly story? Check.

author: {'steamid': '76561198149222284', 'num_games_owned': 1907, 'num_reviews': 140, 'playtime_forever': 357, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 357, 'last_played': 1662469970}
review:
No Time to Explain is a simple (but nicely) styled platformer where you launch or pull yourself around with various tools. It has a fun story with hidden jokes and references. The game is a little short (for a 15euro game), but that's alright. Better to end a bit short than to be dragged out past the point of fun.

I would almost recommend this game, but the thing with No Time to Explain is it's controls. It just isnt good. On top of that the cusor moves with both your own mouse movement as well as the characters movement. Some levels can still be done easily while others not so much. I experienced this more as an annoyance rather that being faced with a challenging level. 

If not for the controls the game would have been great. Unfortunately I can not recommend this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198249985896', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 68, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1657998944}
review:
Short 2D platform game with a completely absurd narrative. Controls are creative and very fun to play with. The game itself isn't too hard, but the unusual controls coupled with the physics-based mechanics can make some of the later sequences hard to master. Nothing outrageously complex if you have experience with the type of game. I like how the game wastes no time with a main menu and just throws you into the action.

While the artwork feels minimalist and very reminiscent of flash games, I found it worked perfectly with the whole ambience and the animations are fluid, and funny enough!

The game crashed on me twice when I changed windows. I don't know if it has anything to do with the forced resolution of the screen, but I'd recommend not switching windows too much while playing, or using 2 screens. It only happened at a beginning of a level (thus after an auto-save), so it wasn't too much of a problem in my case.

All in all, I really enjoyed this little game! 15$ might seem a bit on the high size compared to other similarly priced games, but I wouldn't call it insulting, especially considering the size of the developers team.
8/10

review: It's not a bad game but man I really dislike having to set myself on fire and having to platform within 4 seconds to burn the wooden wall or die. I don't remember buying this and it is fun but not my cup of tea. If you never tried it, its interesting to say the least. But this is probably on a flash site for free because the entire game feels like it was taken from coolmathgames.com I cannot see myself bothering to finish the game because the entire game is you fighting the controls. It's quirky at first but annoying later. I can't say I'm mad at but this game has been in my backlog for almost a year now and after playing an hour I do not wish to suffer any further.

[h3]ğŸ’¬ Comments ğŸ’¬[/h3]
[h2]Short Game Description[/h2]
No Time To Explain Remastered, it's an interesting platform game that it's fine, with different mechanics that you need to use them in boss fights.
[list]
[*][h3]Positives[/h3]
Talking about the positives, the game has different mechanics for their thematic levels and bosses that lead to a quite challenging game.
[*][h3]Negatives[/h3]
About the negatives the game in some levels or collectibles asks you to do something pretty hard, in comparison to next levels.
[/list][h2][u]Conclusion[/u][/h2]
The game is nothing special, if you have some spare money left, you can buy it to have a little fun time with it. The game is a 6/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198258462991', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 294, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 294, 'last_played': 1676394929}
review: I enjoyed the first general part of the game, not taking it seriously and frankly, I feel like I lucky shot my way through as far as I have gotten. I found it odd the game is overall rated positively yet as of right now only 7.6% of players got the achievement for finishing the game. The game is pretty short overall so that was a shocker at first, but not anymore. I see why there has been numerous reviews with complaints about the controls. I've tried both a controller and the original PC controls but I find even with the controller (which I personally found significantly better) it still left much to be desired. I enjoy a challenge, but if most of my shots need to either be perfectly aligned or boiling down to pure luck, I see why the majority of players appear to abandon the game. I was pretty hyped up after the trailer, and glad I got this on sale at least. I agree with the other reviews that full price would not be worth it, and honestly, I'm disappointed enough that I wish I'd played this game straight away when I bought it so I might have a chance at refunding it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198210857320', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 21, 'playtime_forever': 439, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 439, 'last_played': 1649678701}
review:
No instructions, no tutorial. There's literally NO TIME TO EXPLAIN.
This is a really smart platformer that challenges the usual and expected gameplay mechanics, as you use your weapon to destroy stuff and to propel yourself in the air.
It's very brutal in a hilarious way, with a crazy story that will leave you smiling.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992438116', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 497, 'playtime_forever': 449, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 438, 'last_played': 1649174021}
review: Not Time To Explain est un sympathique jeu de plateforme. Les rÃ¨gles changent au fil des diffÃ©rents niveaux, variant ainsi le gameplay. Le principe est simple, notre double venant du futur arrive pour nous avertir d'un sombre prÃ©sage et tout part en cacahuÃ¨te Ã  ce moment lÃ . Va s'en suivre de nombreuses courses poursuites afin de progresser. Le jeu est colorÃ© et se base sur le "die and retry". On apprend petit Ã  petit Ã  maÃ®triser notre personnage et l'Ã©volution de ses mouvements au fil des niveaux. Le jeu se terminera en 4 Ã  5 heures en fonction de votre facilitÃ© Ã  assimiler les dÃ©placements. Au final un jeu qui ravira le joueur occasionnel comme l'amateur de speedrun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198043066079', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 12270, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9161, 'last_played': 1691775867}
review: A really fun little game to play casually, and can usually be finished in 1 to 3 hours, depending on how quickly you get a hang of the controls. Afterwards, if you still like the game, it's amazing for speedrunning, with quite high skill ceiling, and just a bit of luck to keep it spicy. Often goes on sale, so put in on your wishlist to get notified :)

author: {'steamid': '76561198025187473', 'num_games_owned': 688, 'num_reviews': 213, 'playtime_forever': 117, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 117, 'last_played': 1640760500}
review:
Good game, simple controls, but also sloppy.

[h1]Controls[/h1][list]
[*]A and D to move left and right [i][b]slowly[/b][/i]
[*]Hold LMB to fire your gun for the purpose of flying and quick movement[/list]

[h1]Gamelay[/h1][list]
[*][i]Pray the game's physics let you properly move to avoid being hurt[/i] because understandably being lifted off the ground by the force of your weapon is difficult to control.
[*]You die in one hit and have to restart from your last checkpoint, however unlike other indie platformers, these devs don't expect you to master the game by the second level.
[*]Any time your feet touch the ground is counted as a checkpoint, so you can complete levels with little to no frustration
[*]Bosses operate on a 4 life system, you get to respawn three times during a fight.
I gave up on the game after my fifth attempt at the third boss.[/list]

[h1]The third boss[/h1][list]
[*]The third boss has these four gravity orbs which bend your laser, so you have to be standing in specific parts of the level to even hit it.
[*]There is also falling debris which you have to constantly dodge and move fast enough that you need to have a quick reaction time to dodge them, most of the time I lost a life was due to these hitting me within a second of them coming into view.
[*]The finally, the boss has a shield that you need to whittle away multiple times to expose its HP, then after a few seconds it comes down and makes the ground kill you, so you need to quick get on top of debris to avoid being killed while also continuing to avoid additional falling debris.[/list]
That said I didn't hate it, so it gets a good review from me.

author: {'steamid': '76561198056902770', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 294, 'playtime_forever': 236, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 236, 'last_played': 1604941142}
review:
[b]â€From 2011 with loveâ€[/b]
[i]-James Bond[/i]
[hr][/hr]

From an era of either AAA or flash games with sparse in-betweens, [b]No Time To Explain[/b] immediately made a name for itself.
But, you may be asking, is it still worth it this many years down the line?

Yes...ish.

[h1]X-Factor[/h1]
The major selling point is the humor and the simple gameplay that never re-threads the same thing, every time you'll have a feeling that something is going to get stale it switches up the gameplay.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
You have a huge laser beam...
That's cool and all, but where are the enemies?
There aren't many, the laser is mainly used to propel you in the opposite direction in order to clear platforming challenges, this switches up to a grenade that lets you rocket jump, or a slime ball that functions like a sling.

[h1]Story[/h1]
Thereâ€™s no time to explain the story, Iâ€™ll let you experience it yourself.

[h1]Downsides[/h1]
Thereâ€™s the occasional bump in difficulty due to some levels that the devs either didnâ€™t test or thought it was cool filling long levels with precision platforming in a game about momentum and praying you land in a good spot or long levels with one hit kills everywhere, but still these levels are rare.
[hr][/hr]

All and all there is some good variety, I donâ€™t know how much remastering a game is hard but the crafty buggers slapped on a once free game a pricetag of 15$ almost feeling like theyâ€™re exploiting the average asking price of nowadays indie game, still, I had fun so I have to recommend this.

author: {'steamid': '76561198081323567', 'num_games_owned': 524, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 85, 'last_played': 1603724991}
review: A platformer from the era of â€˜screaming random thingsâ€™ humour, and it shows it. This game would be much more enjoyable if more effort were put into polishing the game design, which is decidedly rough around the edges, and less into the â€˜lol randomâ€™ voice lines and narrative. Hiding behind some incredibly irritating boss design and unreliable mechanics are some excellent, well-thought-through concepts; but they are poorly implemented. An excellent soundtrack is drowned out by gratingly poor sound design.

author: {'steamid': '76561198970254440', 'num_games_owned': 1532, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 429, 'last_played': 1679061214}
review: I ended up getting this game for a couple of dollars in a bundle, I thought it would be lame but I ended up playing for 6 hours my first load up of the game, This game is comical, has a nice weird mechanic for movement, but its strangely satisfying when you hit the portals just right. The story is so far a 7/10, but there's really no time to explain, it just throws you into the game right off, lol.

O jogo nÃ£o tÃªm historia, o que Ã© chato pra mim, mas pra muita gente pode nÃ£o fazer diferenÃ§a, o jogador deve usar sua arma laser como impulso pra avanÃ§ar pelos levels (a maioria bem curtos), algumas vezes a arma muda e a mecÃ¢nica Ã© alterada por algum tempo, mas Ã© sempre a mesma premissa, praticamente a arma Ã© o unica cosia importante.
O que achei chato Ã© que nÃ£o Ã© habilidade que te faz avanÃ§ar, mas sim morrer e ir ajustando milimetricamente sua mira pro proximo disparo te dar um impulso um pouco mais favorÃ¡vel, o jogo Ã© desafiador, isso Ã© verdade, mas tambÃ©m Ã© chato ficar repetindo as mesmas coisas atÃ© encontrar o Ãºnico movimento exato pra avanÃ§ar, dizem que o jogo tÃªm 2 horas se o jogador  avanÃ§ar direto, nÃ£o devo ter avanÃ§ado muito mais que 1 hora descartando o tempo perdido, e nÃ£o foi um tempo divertido.
NÃ£o recomendo principalmente com esse preÃ§o, que acho muito pesado, entÃ£o aconselho esperar um desconto. Se quiser mesmo comprar  recomendo assistir um gameplay primeiro.
----------------------------------------------
Born as a free game by Newgrounds in 2011, it later became a full game No Time To Explain then received a Remastered which luckily is free for those who have the first paid version, I think the game idea is very good, but the execution is not. It's.
The game has no history, which is boring to me, but for a lot of people it may not matter, the player must use his laser weapon as a boost to advance through the levels (mostly very short), sometimes the weapon changes and the mechanics is changed for some time, but it's always the same premise, practically the weapon is the only important thing.
What I found annoying is that it's not skill that makes you advance, but dying and finely adjusting your aim for the next shot to give you a little more favorable boost, the game is challenging, that's true, but it's also boring to keep repeating the same things until I find the single exact move to advance, they say the game has 2 hours if the player advances straight, I shouldn't have advanced much more than 1 hour discarding lost time, and it wasn't a fun time.
I don't recommend it especially at this price, which I think is too heavy, so I advise waiting for a discount. If you really want to buy, I recommend watching a gameplay first.

author: {'steamid': '76561198220436820', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 650, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 650, 'last_played': 1618170694}
review: A pretty fun and cool game all around! The writing and story is freaking hilarious all the way through! The game is constantly throwing new ideas your way! If I had any complaint at all it would be that some of those ideas are annoying or some of the levels are just insanely harder than others. If you are a platformer lover like me or just wanna play through a wacky story then I totally recommend this game!

author: {'steamid': '76561198066905165', 'num_games_owned': 549, 'num_reviews': 101, 'playtime_forever': 45, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 45, 'last_played': 1622451145}
review:
I know I am gonna be a bit harsh but there is really a problem with these games getting "very positive" reviews on Steam, this takes away a bit of visibility from the games that are truly good (whether indies or AAA).

I wanted for force myself to play this "No time to explain" a little further, but it was bad from the start and I couldn't help but to drop after less than an hour. The game is a clunky platformer which basically relies on the shots of your weapon to make you jump or fly above obstacles. This gameplay, although simple, is extremely cumbersome and inaccurate. It is almost impossible to manage a precise jump correctly. The physics behind the propulsion of the weapon feel very unnatural, and this gameplay inherently bonds together your movements and your shots. Some may find it interesting, I find it just plain annoying.

Addtionally, the game desperately tries to give itself some kind of crazy humour, but the result is not funny for one second and very cringy.

Steer clear !

author: {'steamid': '76561198178355143', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 495, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 416, 'last_played': 1706030793}
review:
This game still holds up really well. It's a nice level of challenging that doesn't get so difficult that it reaches into rage game territory (like some people say).

On top of it being really mechanically solid its also really funny. The story is super cliche and over the top but totally knows it. Every new level feels like its one-upping itself with how crazy it can make things.

I snagged the game for free from a good Samaritan over on discord, special thanks to SadAlcoholic. I feel 15 bucks is a pretty fair price for this although I do recommend you wait for it to go on sale.

author: {'steamid': '76561198994796062', 'num_games_owned': 227, 'num_reviews': 87, 'playtime_forever': 274, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 274, 'last_played': 1597515039}
review:
This game saved my life.

I am 43.

My ex-wife and I have a daughter together, and adopted our son together. They are now both 4 years old.

When we were going through our separation, I found myself lost and miserable. I was self destructive. I got so mad one day from everything spiralling out of my control that I punched some concrete in a moment of overwhelming emotion. That caused me to break my 5th metacarpal in my right hand... my working hand... my games hand.. the hand that I held and carried my children to bed with.. The hand I desperately needed to make sure I could continue to provide.

After learning of the severity of my self-inflicted damage, I was borderline suicidal. Keep in mind that just a few months before this, I was the happiest man with no history of depression or anxiety. I have never had fits of rage, or been one to break down and cry, but I was in a low spot that just really buried me from being able to see the light on the other side.

Having nothing better to do, I searched for a game I could play, ONE HANDED while I recovered. I somehow stumbled upon this game and read some of the reviews. I decided that it had to be worth a shot... I must admit, I didn't beat the game, or play nearly as long as some of you. In fact, I may have only played this game a day or two.. With that being said, after doing so, I had a new found joy and hope for life. I was able to put behind me the pain and suffering that had been cast over me. I was able to experience other peoples joy and happiness. I was able to see the fruits of my "labor". I relaxed for 5 â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥â™¥ minutes to this music long enough to realize that I was going to be okay.

After coming to that realization, I turned the game off, and I went back to work. It hurt my hand like hell but I was motivated. I stopped feeling so damn sorry for myself, and I became the father I needed to be in that moment, not the weak boy I was behaving as.

Today, I am close friend with my kids mother. We don't fight, or argue, or say hurtful things to each other. We are parents, and friends.

I now have 3 kids. My third child is, wait for it, ALSO 4 YEARS OLD. The woman I am with was going through a very similar situation at the time of my own separation, and we just stumbled in to each others life unexpectedly. We have been in a relationship for a year now, and are very happy together.

Moral of the story, you never know what life holds in store for you, and if I would have given up when all the odds were stacked against me, I wouldn't be where I am today. This silly little game helped me realize that.

Thank you.

author: {'steamid': '76561198030784015', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 11208, 'playtime_forever': 229, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 229, 'last_played': 1617618841}
review:
No Time To Explain is a browser/flash based 2D platformer with MS Paint tier art.  You've got some laser thing you can use to push yourself around and blast things with,

The fact that this is basically a Flash game being sold on Steam for $15 should be enough to warn anyone away.  It really is that bad, and it's a fine example of everything that's wrong with the "indie" game development movement.

author: {'steamid': '76561197975960529', 'num_games_owned': 1444, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 299, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 299, 'last_played': 1616370849}
review:
Due to this game being fairly short, I am not going to use spoiler tags in this review.  Please do not read this if you want to avoid any spoilers (though I am not going to go out of my way to spoil the game itself).

I went into "No Time To Explain" Remastered wanting to love it.  I had seen the opening intro with the crab way before, but didn't realize the exact enemy of this game.

The controls.

The controls are utter garbage.  Looking at the response from the developer, according to them, "the gamepad controls just fine".  Where was this version and can this be uploaded to Steam?!

And according to the store page, this game has "full controller support".

I suppose, technically, that's true.  I mean, the gamepad is supported.  The problem is that the stick on the gamepad is used to control your beam - and it doesn't have anywhere *near* the precision it needs to get you through the spikes, and whatever asinine "hazards of the day" the game places in front of you without a ton of tweaking and minor little adjustments that you better hope you got right because if not yet another death is coming your way.  Have fun starting over!

Not to mention there are some level "power ups" that, could be described as hazards, that if you have them too long you just die and not even start over from your most recent ledge - but start over from the beginning of the level.

That's not to say that all the levels are bad.  Most of them are fine.  A lot of them feature "hats" in hard to reach places.  Eventually, I got so frustrated with the controls that, if the hat wasn't pretty much directly in my path to the goal, I didn't bother.  Why would I?  I've had enough deaths due to the horrid controls - I don't need any more arbitrary controller-induced deaths to get meaningless macguffins that barely alter the character's appearance.  You're still a super tiny sprite with a gun, when all the hats are accounted for.  Their collection isn't worth suffering through the controls more than you need to.

Now let's get to the boss battles.  Talk about repetition.  Find the weakness.  Figure out where to camp in the stage to hit the weakness continually.  Dodge the boss' repeated pattern with the horrid controls hoping you don't die due to either that, or let's say an arbitrarily placed spike on the side of a fish tank for example - why is that even there?  Because the controls aren't enough to kill you by running into the boss - we've got to add spikes.  Who doesn't like spikes?!  But why do I say "where to camp?"  Because, unfortunately, using the gun as a movement device comes with a physics kickback.  So, you have to find just the right spot to be able to hold down the trigger - which, very late in the game, gets *replaced* with something else which should have been on the bumper (this is a cardinal sin! NEVER remap the controls in the game once you've introduced them, unless it's a completely different moveset like flying vs driving!) and now the beam is on the bumper.  Anyways, you have to find the right spot because while the beam will shoot with the stick, I found that it would constantly stop doing it as the stick and your finger try to center.  So holding down the trigger during the boss fights was pretty much the only option.

I'm not surprised about (as of this writing) only about 8% of players (myself included) have bothered to beat the game.  When you beat it, the credits roll, and the team says this is their first game.  Believe me. We know.  It's very raw.

Is there anthing to like about this game?  I thought the cutscenes were pretty well done, very reminiscent of Newgrounds flash cartoons back in the game.  There is a level very close to the end that plays with filling in the levels via your beam, and would have been a good section if it wasn't A. very, very short and B. just masturbatory fodder for the developer to claim their game as art (there is a cutscene that precedes this with a sterotypical artsy-fartsy guy pondering are games art, but at this point in the game, in my head I said "Not your game, that's for sure!")  There's also a powerup you get in the middle that is a shotgun thing that returns later for a brief time that was fun to play around with, since you didn't have to constantly point a stick in a direction - a precise direction with precise timing - in order to not die with it.  Other movement systems were also featured - none of which were very good with the controller.  Obviously I was able to stick it out to the end, but the controls kill this game.

When you beat the game - which the 92% of you reading this review will never do, according to the Steam stats - it unlocks levels that I presume fans made.  And they are *so much better* than the ones in the main game that were super frustrating.  These people seem to know the limitations of this game more than the developers themselves - which is painful.  Again, most of the levels are decent - but a few of them (I'm looking at you, spike wall to explosion to ramp to spike corridor descent!) are so painful to try to get right with the controller and just the physics being finicky that it's enraging.

This game is probably fun to watch with someone who knows the *exact* angles and timing and can pull it off all the time - but for the 8% who beat this game, I am betting that only the top 0.05% can do that with the awful controls.  Watch a playthrough for the story and the cutscenes (the music isn't bad, either), but otherwise this game's a design in frustration.  I hope for better games in the future from this developer that focus on nailing down playing the game without super precision that isn't available in the non-remappable controls provided for a gamepad.

And no, I'm not using the keyboard and mouse - I hook my PC to a TV and play via a controller.  It works for all the games that say "full controller support" - except for the few, like this one, that offer that support in name only.

review: Fun and underrated game. Confusing storyline in the funniest way possible. If you aren't feeling too good about it from the start, remember that the original game was released in two parts. author: {'steamid': '76561198133750825', 'num_games_owned': 358, 'num_reviews': 80, 'playtime_forever': 42, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 14, 'last_played': 1609183777}
review:
I've been playing this game for about 45 minutes and its already infuriating to me. If you've played the original I imagine its a little easier, but going into this game without knowing anything about the first one is a slap in the face. The movement is slow, jumps are useless, so the only way you can move around with any sense of speed is with the gun. This gun controls like ass. You are shot in the opposite direction of the beam, and it retains a ton of momentum, meaning it feels unresponsive and slippery. Boosting your jump with the beam feels unpredictable, and the height you gain is relative to the distance you are from the ground. This feels so terrible. Imagine if in super mario sunshine, when you used fludd to hover around, you could only hover when you were 2 feet off the ground, and using the move while above that threshold would do absolutely nothing. I know that giving you more control over movement would break the game, but for gods sake I can't make this jump on like the 9th level consistently.

The worst part is that everytime you die you have to watch the person you're chasing continue to bleed out and they say some stupid fucking oneliner like "oh my god all my blood". It gets old SO fast and I'm immediately looking for a way to turn that off. I can only imagine how you would feel if you actually purchased this game. 

The biggest middle finger to me is that I know everything in this game that I've complained about can be better! Legitimately! Around the middle of the second world you get to play as another character with a different gun, a shotgun, which is better at jumping high, he gets to regain a ton of air movement while flying, and everytime you respawn you don't need to watch another fucking cutscene! Why the hell was he not the main character! 

If you like this game, please keep enjoying it. Having a remastered version of an old flash game is very important, and I can totally see this game clicking with people. I just cannot play this game at all. 

TL;DR: this game is a product of its time. while some games like super meat boy or binding of isaac can pull off this humor or artstyle by having good game design and rewarding movement, this game feels lacking. Enjoy it if you can, but I definitely will not recommend it to anyone who has not played this game before.

review:
No time to explain is a great 2D platformer. The story is absolutely stupid, but super fun and contains lots of humour.

The concept is simple, but enjoyable and too long to explain in detail. But you will basically have a gun that shoots a laser, which you can use in order to fly up for a couple of seconds or to destroy stuff. I would describe this as a puzzle adventure platformer. The interesting part is that you will switch the â€œweaponâ€ in the different levels, which changes the concept and helps the game staying interesting (instead of being too repetitive).

The controls are fluent, and the art style is comic-book-like and looks really nice.

The game can be finished in 2 hours. There are some bonus levels though.

This was TinyBuildâ€™s first game. Look how far they got now. Congratulations! Great first game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198040870627', 'num_games_owned': 178, 'num_reviews': 46, 'playtime_forever': 81, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 8, 'last_played': 1610060082}
review:
"Remastered" to mean not at all. No resolution options, game crashed when trying to leave fullscreen three times. Then it felt like the physics were broken? Like, the stuff the intro levels themselves are even expecting of you wouldn't work half the time. I fire straight down, I get sent upward 2 feet. I fire down again from the same position, I fly up 500 feet. The framerate is caped at 60 so that ain't it so I don't even know.

Get one of their newer/better games. This is unforgivable for a 5 year old game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198153395359', 'num_games_owned': 1003, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 560, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 560, 'last_played': 1597108911}
review:
This is the remaster of a Flash-based puzzle platformer with boss battles and lackluster controls. This is not a bad game, but you can find better nowadays.

With multiple mechanics constantly phasing in and out, you will find many ways to catapult yourself or change the environment around you, though only one or two are available in each level, with a few notable exceptions. Mastering the controls is part of the challenge and, while satisfactory, can lead to frustration.

The map design greatly benefits from each stage's unique mechanic, turning them into more than a simple gimmick. A few of the maps are annoyingly hard, requiring either extreme precision or luck, to the point of being unfunny, but that's usually not the case. It unfortunately lack some modern conveniences, like saving the game inside a stage, forcing you to plan around those limitations.

Boss battles are surprisingly good, but far from a cakewalk. Each boss has a unique and well defined pattern, exploiting it is key for your success. Mastery of the stage's mechanics are also tested, but you can cheese your way into victory once you understand the boss's inner workings.

The game's writing is its selling point, with a well-crafted timeline that makes sense in hindsight and a quirky sense of humor. It didn't make me burst into laughter, but it was never annoying and it knew when to take itself seriously, despite its randomness.

A normal playthrough takes only 2 to 4 hours, not counting the collectibles and achievements. The game's longevity is greatly expanded by those, with most of the collectibles placed almost out of reach or requiring out-of-the-box thinking. You get almost no achievements by beating the game, but by completing humorous tasks, like beating a stage while dancing and using a specific hat. You have to go out of your way to get them, but it is a great complement to the game's writing.

It is a product of its time while holding surprisingly well. Asking price is a little too high, but I recommend it if you can get it for cheap.

[h1]Rating:[/h1]
[h1]6/10[/h1]

review:
Pros:
-Fun Bosses (as long as you have the [i] figure out the pattern [/i] mentality, and not the [i] haha weapon go [b]brrr[/b][/i] one)
-The good levels are [b] Really [/b]fun, although not all levels are fun
-There is multiplayer support (which i haven't played), that seems pretty fun
-Gives a really good newgrounds/flash nostalgia
-Has some quality humor

Cons:
-Short
-Next to no replay value (no other reviews really exceed 5 hours, so i guess i'm not the only one that thinks that)
-Inconsistent levels (there are really fun levels, and really tedious levels)

Although i recommend this game, it is definetely not worth 15â‚¬ - get on sale

author: {'steamid': '76561198136269787', 'num_games_owned': 439, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 556, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 512, 'last_played': 1672883601}
review:
Lo pase hace como 4 aÃ±os cuando me lo regalaron (supongo que por tener un juego de tinyBuild, SpeedRunners) y lo recordaba mucho mejor, lo volvi a jugar para completarlo al 100% pero fue horrible, con teclado y raton es jugable pero no disfrutable, es muy incomodo apuntar con el mouse pero cuando lo jugue con mando, era otro mundo, mucho mas facil y comodo.

El juego es muy bueno, tiene comedia y una dificultad elevada (exceptuando los jefes), y en algunos casos debes pensar para resolver los niveles y no solo seguir para adelante, lo recomiendo pero esperaria a una oferta.

IMPORTANTE: El juego esta capado a 60 fps esto hace que aveces se sienta lento y NO se puede cambiar la resolucion, esta como a 1280x720 o una similar.

review: Worth it if this game comes to your collection in a bundle or at a very steep discount of a few dollars or less. Best played in short bursts because of how repetitive it is. Controls can sometimes feel inconsistent but overall is enjoyable enough to keep me coming back every now and then.

author: {'steamid': '76561198365289813', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 64, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1675042273}
review:
The story is odd and funny, the gameplay is challenging but not frustrating. and most importantly, the music is bangin.

Not gonna lie though, I would recommend a controller (and headphones) to play this, joystick over mouse anyday with this game.

OH AND IT HAS SPLITSCREEN! I realise that most here on steam won't find that useful, but as someone with younger siblings I always appreciate a developer that goes out of their way to add it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198024762848', 'num_games_owned': 425, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 126, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1594102507}
review:
It's okay, but it's [i]very[/i] short. I beat it in 2 hours and that was with me getting stuck at some points. I've played Flash games longer than this.

This game isn't nearly as hard as some people say. I suck at video games but got through this easily. There are some tricky bits, but I'd rank other indie platformers (VVVVVV, Super Meat Boy, etc.) as being harder.

The main movement mechanic (read: gimmick) sounds cool on paper, but in practice, is frustrating. The laser cannon doesn't apply that much force towards you, making it feel less like a test of skill and more like wrestling with the controls. It doesn't strike that balance of satisfying controls and difficult levels like in other indie platformers. There are points in the game where you control other characters with other gimmicks, and frankly they are much more enjoyable to play.

The humor will be very familiar to anyone who went on Newgrounds during its heyday. To any [strike]degenerate zoomers[/strike] youngsters who are reading this, Newgrounds was a site that acted as a hub for original animations and games (and porn but we don't talk about that). This game reeks of 2005 "lol randum xD" humor. If you're a 30-year-old boomer, this humor might appeal to you. However, anyone of good taste will see it's very dated.

Overall: If you buy this at full price, you're a moron. Buy this in a bundle or at a [i]steep[/i] discount.

author: {'steamid': '76561198256879471', 'num_games_owned': 171, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 223, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 205, 'last_played': 1616807141}
review:
A masterpiece from a bygone age. Get it on sale and enjoy the chaos that is this game.

A lot of reviews on Steam will mention this feels like an old Newgrounds game, and I agree - because that's actually what it is, a browser game brought forward. Don't anticipate a coherent storyline or smooth graphics because that isn't what this game is. I agree that it isn't quite worth the full price, but at half price or less I'd say go for it. 

The controls are finicky and not easily mastered. It does, at times, feel frustratingly difficult, but part of this game is that you have to keep trying and learn the levels a bit. It takes time to 'feel out' what you need to do to get where you're going, but if you're willing to give it patience, it has plenty to give in return. Don't let it deter you with the difficulty and don't be afraid of dying, a lot. 

With that said, if you aren't scared away by that, then this is definitely worth it. The chaotic storyline, interesting game mechanics and sweet music are the main draws, and even though it's ridiculous, I found myself enjoying the crazy in this game. The level design is pretty smart but it's clear what you need to do, and the secrets are well hidden. My only complaints are that at one point one of the sound effects started looping (fixed by a restart) and that one particular gun comes with a repeated sound effect that could have used a lot less frequency. Both were solved by simply turning off sound effects. (The screen shake was also irritating, but I suppose necessary. I'll give it a pass.)

TLDR: forgive it for being the full version of a flash game and there's a gem hidden within.

author: {'steamid': '76561198055559456', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 69, 'playtime_forever': 213, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 156, 'last_played': 1592600293}
review:
Good gameplay, interesting mechanics, and what I enjoyed most was that it was genuinely quite funny.

Ignore the idiots saying the controls are wonky or the movement is floaty, somehow they missed the whole point of the game, which is mastering that movement. You'll die a lot in the beginning but there is no consequence to it. By the end it will feel natural and you'll know where and how to aim to reach a certain place.

The only thing I would criticise is the price. I got this game in a Humble Bundle, however I would say that this game is probably only worth around 5$ not on sale. It only took around 3 hours to beat, and with this game being released in 2015, the price really should have been dropped by now.

If you want a fun little platformer get this one during a sale!

author: {'steamid': '76561198146227846', 'num_games_owned': 391, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 311, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 224, 'last_played': 1637874769}
review:
I love this game. The mechanics are amazing and used very well, however some bits were frustrating for no reason. In one level, it is just one long jump- easy right? well it is if you knew beforehand that you were supposed to have the mouse facing the bottom left then click, but for most it sort of dragged on. 

The humour was great and so were the bosses, my favourite being the shark.

I loved playing as other characters, such as the football player who launches himself in the air in one burst to travel but I wish you kept them for the rest of the level.

author: {'steamid': '76561197998960195', 'num_games_owned': 553, 'num_reviews': 11, 'playtime_forever': 11, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 11, 'last_played': 1590460302}
review: I wanted to like this game, as the premise is something I find humorous, but yeah, no. Playing with an Xbox 360 controller left me feeling stuck in only the second level, and after listening to repeated screams after dying 20+ times, I was done. Maybe the experience is better on keyboard and mouse, or maybe I was just missing something entirely, but the experience was frustrating and I have other games I can play.

author: {'steamid': '76561197982484630', 'num_games_owned': 411, 'num_reviews': 54, 'playtime_forever': 220, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1590909843}
review:
Nice little 2D platformer game. The story is seemingly wild and nonsensical, but makes sense on some bizarre, internal level. Cute music and creative level design.

The character movement seem a bit imprecise, I had a lot of moments when I was thinking to myself "how did I not land on that surface?". Almost as if the character hitbox is different than the visual representation.

Most levels seems smooth, although in some cases I would get stuck for 10 minutes in a room, constantly repeating a sequence of jumps just to get to that one I'd always fail. It made me feel like a video game journalist sometimes.

Good as long as you can get it for couple bucks and don't want to be playing it more than 20 minutes at a time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011086924', 'num_games_owned': 1083, 'num_reviews': 436, 'playtime_forever': 232, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 232, 'last_played': 1589708682}
review: NOT a perfect game but it was TinyBuild's FIRST game so what can ya do? I love the humor but gameplay could be more polished for a co-op game. Download Parsec and host a game of you and 3 others. It is very clunky with co-op as somewhat of an after thought but it is doable. I just spent a few hours beating it with friends. Sadly a cutscene or 2 got skipped by a fellow player but that's what you risk on Parsec. Anyway, grab it for cheap. It's decent fun and there are 2 bonus levels at the end. They are challenge maps. Most of my problems are for multiplayer so I won't bother saying them since this was built with singleplayer in mind so I can't complain. I wouldn't spend more than 5 for it though unless you bleed for goofy games in which case cheap fun is your thing and might as well spend what you want for you niche.

author: {'steamid': '76561198075324976', 'num_games_owned': 909, 'num_reviews': 689, 'playtime_forever': 548, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1588755004}
review:
Totally worth $1.50 when on 90% off sale.

Really stretching it when asking $15 full price.

This is a physics platformer with terrible floaty controls that exercises your patience as much as it does your skills. The humor is funny, but repetitive and the difficulty curve is as much luck as it is learning. I can recommend it because it's funny and is fun in short bursts, but only at sale prices. This is not worth anywhere near the full price as it's just a remastered flash game that used to be free.
---

author: {'steamid': '76561198290206794', 'num_games_owned': 108, 'num_reviews': 14, 'playtime_forever': 457, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1692686973}
review: This game holds a special place in my heart. I played it back when it was introduced on newgrounds, and after a couple years i forgot about it. Coming back to it, I forgot what a fun experience it was. This game is simple in its design and the humor never overstays its welcome. I have to say for me, it falls into the very small category of games that make me wish I could experience the whole thing for the first time all over again. The lovable characters, creative maps, good jokes, satisfying gameplay and wonderful design all work together to create a game that at no point becomes boring. Honestly, one of my favorite games from my past. 10/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198046450713', 'num_games_owned': 448, 'num_reviews': 133, 'playtime_forever': 144, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 144, 'last_played': 1586753782}
review:
No time to explain is a quirky, cool looking, fast to learn, and unique indie game that got made into a full game with a budget to do all the things they wanted to do as a flash game dev. I had a lot of fun with this game and getting all of the achievements was a pain, but I would still recommend it to anyone who enjoys platformer games.

All of my hours are in the older version that got kicked off of steam.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044917985', 'num_games_owned': 328, 'num_reviews': 141, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1463936127}
review:
There is so much time to explain

No Time to Explain is a platform action video game developed and published by tinyBuild.[1] Designed by Tom Brien and Alex Nichiporchik, it is the successor to Brien's browser game, released on January 6, 2011. No Time to Explain has been released on Linux, Microsoft Windows, and OS X. A remastered version of the game, No Time to Explain Remastered, was released for Linux, Microsoft Windows, OS X, PlayStation 4, and Xbox One.
The game follows an unnamed male protagonist as he chases his future self, who has been captured, through time for an unknown reason. Central to the game is a powerful laser gun received from the Future Protagonist that can be used as both a weapon and a means of propulsion. A running gag is that, just as a character is about to explain what's going on, they are interrupted, keeping the protagonist - and the player - in the dark.

The plot contains elements of time travel, the time paradox effect, and alternate time-lines. As the game continues, the characters and worlds get increasingly more absurd, including a world made entirely of desserts and a blank world that must be painted with "ink" (via the gun) to traverse. The player will also control several alternate versions of the protagonists, such as the football helmet wearing "Shotgun Guy," who uses his namesake to propel himself over large distances.

Eventually, the culprit behind the attacks is discovered: the protagonist's evil twin, who was released by accident while the protagonist was chasing his abducted selves. Once all the levels are completed, a round table of protagonist versions convenes to come up with a plan. The group misunderstands a brainstorm from the original protagonist and graft him and Shotgun Guy together into a composite being, giving the player the ability to use both types of guns. The plan somehow works, but moments before defeat, the evil twin goes back to the beginning of the game with Composite Guy in pursuit. The original protagonist is killed after the twin steals the laser gun, the twin is then pushed into the attacking monster he released, and after a few awkward moments of silence, the composite protagonist finally announces, "Video Games!" Then, the credits roll.

review:
Neat fun game. Plenty of charm. It's kinda short and the graphics are okay, but that's to be expected from an old game.
It was an enjoyable 3 hours. It might turn to 4 or 5 if I try getting all the hats or achievements.
There's also a workshop for more levels if you want more, but I think the short and sweet playthrough was enough for me.

review: Feels like an old Newgrounds flash game with unpleasant physics. The puzzles and bosses themselves are fine, but the main blaster beam mechanic for movement is not very fun and the occasional humorous voice lines don't make up for it. Skip.

review: Definitely a fun and rewarding challenge, this game likes to shake things up once in a while with level design and varied control systems.  Would definitely advise controller play, and be aware that the difficulty spikes in a few places.

author: {'steamid': '76561198001494272', 'num_games_owned': 1309, 'num_reviews': 335, 'playtime_forever': 581, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 581, 'last_played': 1478409064}
review: Plays with some interesting movement mechanics, but escalates the difficulty too quickly. The comedy is minimal, dated, and cringey more often than not. Still doesn't control like a remaster, and doesn't do enough interesting ideas to recommend.

author: {'steamid': '76561198006053403', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 13, 'playtime_forever': 51, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 51, 'last_played': 1576599284}
review: Alright, this review is hard for me because I genuinely love the writing and vibe of this game, but an unfun difficulty and some frustrating design choices bring it down. To clarify, I LOVE difficult games when they are done properly. Soulsborne games have a difficulty that makes you want to come back and try again. I spent hours in cuphead and loved almost every second of it. This ones difficulty and sometimes frustratingly punishing (although thankfully this is a much less common occurance) handling of checkpoints just makes me want to stop playing. I don't know enough about game design to explain why sadly, but I was put off enough to feel obligated to write this review in hopes that when this game gets a sequel (because PLEASE, I need more of this plot or lack thereof) they dial it back a bit on how punishing it is.

author: {'steamid': '76561198886227993', 'num_games_owned': 168, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 736, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 668, 'last_played': 1569783313}
review:
This game is a fleshed out version of a browser game, which means it's built on a minimalistic idea and not really meant to be a long game. Still, it works well enough to enjoy a weekend or so. Go through time with your Kamehameha Gun and platform to defeat octosharks and giant robot crabs while getting a nice assorted amount of hats along the way.

But if you get the game, do so while on sale. It's entertaining, but also pricey. Remember that at the end of the day, it's still based on a browser game, which should tell you how much quality to expect.

author: {'steamid': '76561198005151347', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 85, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 9, 'last_played': 1570173225}
review:
An interesting idea for core gameplay, and it seems like effort went into coming up with variations on the theme, but one fact kills it - the gunflight (or whatever it's best called) physics are counterintuitive and unnatural. (For example, firing down provides you with an upward boost. If you jump and then boost, you get about half as high as without the jump.) It's something I could probably get used to, but I find I have little interest in doing so.

The humor is...fine. If you thought Newgrounds animations of hemorrhaging cupcakes were hilarious, this will probably amuse.

author: {'steamid': '76561198000082399', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 93, 'playtime_forever': 43, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 43, 'last_played': 1566829663}
review:
Game goes from okay to annoyingly hard and turns into a bullet hell game with a lot of cheap shots. It's also locked in 720p which is just downright pathetic for a 2015 game regardless of the art style. If it was on a console I wouldn't mind but on PC it messes with the desktop resolution as well, so have fun multi-tasking and viewing everything else in 720P as well.

Visually it looked really good, there's a lot of decent visual feedback & audio feedback to compliment it. The audio itself was good, good music but basic sound effects which were fine cause it suited the aesthetic of the game.

The gameplay was rudimentary though, pretty much just fire a laser canon in the opposite direction that you want to move the character. It had some decent platforming which I was mildly enjoying just up until the game went from that, to a crappy bullet hell game. It makes no effort to imply that it even has those kind of mechanics. If I wanted to play a bullet hell game I'd have done so. 

Maybe some day I'll revisit it in local co-op but I doubt even that will really change much.

review:
[h1] Genre [/h1] Ein 2D Platformer mit Puzzle & Action Elementen

[h1] Story [/h1] Unser zukÃ¼nftiges Ich taucht plÃ¶tzlich vor uns auf, hat aber keine Zeit uns zu erzÃ¤hlen was los ist oder warum er hier ist. PlÃ¶tzlich wird er von einer Riesen Krabbe gepackt und mitgeschleift und wir machen uns nun ans Werk uns selbst zu retten.

[h1] Gameplay [/h1] Gleich vorweg, das Spiel ist leicht frustrierend. Man kann zwar Laufen & Springen aber das bringt nicht viel. Man hat eine Laser Waffe die gleichzeitig auch als Jetpack gilt (das macht das voran kommen deutlich schwieriger). Die Einzelnen Level sind relativ kurz aber teilweise schwierig. Gegner gibt es (mit wenigen ausnahmen) nicht. In den Leveln sind Stacheln, Schluchten usw. unser Feind. Es gibt einige Nette Boss KÃ¤mpfe die wirklich SpaÃŸ machen. In den Einzelnen Leveln kann man HÃ¼te einsammeln um unseren Charakter anders aussehen zu lassen.

[h1] Achievements [/h1] Es gibt insgesamt 9 Erfolge. DafÃ¼r muss man alle HÃ¼te im Spiel sammeln und gewisse Bosse ohne zu sterben besiegen. Auch einige Speedrun Erfolge sind mit dabei

[h1] Pro/Contra [/h1]
+ Story Abgedreht aber Cool gemacht
+ Gute Musik
+ Witzig
+ Faire Checkpoints
+ Nette Boss KÃ¤mpfe

author: {'steamid': '76561198095379600', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 26, 'playtime_forever': 705, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 705, 'last_played': 1562493135}
review: Not a bad game, but mediocre. I can see why it could've been popular back in the Flash game days, though it somehow missed my attention until the remaster. The main plus of NTtE is that just as you may start getting bored of the game's mechanics, rest assured they'll be changed almost completely right around the corner. The downside of this is that because of so much different gameplay setups involved, none of them are refined and the level design leaves much to be desired. Despite the remaster, the game still holds a dense Flash game aesthetic, which mostly means that a lot of it is bland semi-hand-drawn shapes, with characters being the worst offenders. Same for music - typical indie game mix of the dramatic and chiptune. Most tracks barely differ from one another. I did have my share of fun with this game, but overall, I feel there was too much frustration with unfair difficulty involved. I do believe if this remaster was more intricate and spent more time refining the mechanics and level design, this could've been a great game. As it is right now, I only recommend buying it on sale, if you're feeling particularly thirsty for some  more run-of-the-mill indie platformer experience.

author: {'steamid': '76561197977904226', 'num_games_owned': 1151, 'num_reviews': 161, 'playtime_forever': 365, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 365, 'last_played': 1560301018}
review:
TinyBuild's debut release has virtually become an icon for the team. With a simple cartoon character from the future being grabbed by a giant crab claw, hints of flash cartoon hilarity seemed apparent from the trailer's viewing.

The graphics are along the Flash quality and the controls are pretty simple. On the other hand, the game mechanics, that require of your timing and coordination with your laser gun, define the challenge that accelerates with each level completed. I can compare it with Super Meat Boy as there are more than a few levels that took many tries to finish; nevertheless satisfying to some level.

The game does get rewarding as the plot unfolds with unpredictable results, considering its dark, humorous nature. Took a few hours to finish it and can be recommended to challenge-seeking fans of platformers, who also appreciate some fresh content of hilarity, and... yes, hats!

review:
Not my type of game at all.
You dont relly run around in the game, you navigate by shooting in the opposite direction of  wich you want to move.
And that is sometimes a hassle especially during boss battles.
Timing shooting in one direction to move and then another to damage and switch back and fort is not fun in my opinion.
It feels like some stages you just beat them by pure luck.

author: {'steamid': '76561198044741485', 'num_games_owned': 188, 'num_reviews': 118, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 182, 'last_played': 1559679808}
review:
No Time To Explain is a 2D platforming game that celebrates innovation. It's fast-paced, unique, and funny.

What makes it so special is all the unique gameplay elements it implements, that often change the way you engage the level you're playing. It doesn't dwell too long on each mechanic, instead choosing to move on to the next.
The game isn't easy, but it's not cheap either. You respawn quickly and next to the jumps you fail, so you can try again right away.

This game is not without flaws, though. The hit detection is sometimes too precise or imprecise, and that can cause frustration. Also, this game is a bit challenging to control with the mouse (I believe it was developed with a controller in mind).

Still, if you like indie games with a twist, No Time To Explain is certainly no exception and it will offer you a few hours of genuine fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198029634846', 'num_games_owned': 120, 'num_reviews': 66, 'playtime_forever': 167, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 167, 'last_played': 1481228211}
review: The game itself is ok. It's just that it feels and looks like a flashgame (it actually even used to be a browser flashgame...) which you'd normally play on one of those "play free games"-websites. The average player also finishes the game within 2-3 hours and there isn't really a reason to ever play it again once you finished the game. Definitely not worth the price, not even on discount. Not to mention that this game has been part of free unlimited giveaways so many times already, so no doubt it will again. If you can't wait for such a moment, I still definitely would not pay more than 1 or 2 dollars for this game.

review:
I've been trying to play this game since I bought it over a year ago and it never loaded normally. The developer stopped respond to such game crashing problems from 2015 so this game is sadly completely abandoned.

I did not ask for a refund because I wanted to play this game so badly, which I regret now. So if you ever want to buy this game, just remember to ask for a refund when you fail to load the game.

review:
Got really stuck on [spoiler] the tunneling mole thing boss [/spoiler] boss.
I've 100% two souls games, so I'm no stranger to difficulty. 
I got so frustrated with this boss that I quit the game. 
The mechanics and atmosphere of this game are good, and I was really enjoying the game at first. But I don't think this game is good enough to keep returning to again and again. And after quitting from frustration once, I don't feel like the mechanics and atmosphere are enough to get me to return.

author: {'steamid': '76561198004565666', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 296, 'playtime_forever': 200, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 200, 'last_played': 1496710578}
review:
Creative and well-designed platformer with some moderately unique ideas, if you can get past the aesthetics.

The main mechanic is that you have a laser with insanely high recoil, and you use the recoil to jump higher, jump farther, fall slower, run faster, etc. It's not quite strong enough to fly (except underwater), but close. The beam itself is used too, to break blocks and damage bosses. Controlling your character precisely is very difficult as the slightest error in angle will send you veering off in the wrong direction, but this is by design.

The game constantly changes things up with new mechanics, most of which stick around for only one level. It'll replace your gun with a different recoil mechanic, or add gravity rotators and cake "powerups" for a puzzle level, add blocks that turn into spikes if you shoot them, etc. Because of this, along with numerous and good-enough boss battles, the gameplay never gets stale and you'll easily keep going to the (relatively short) end. Add in collectible hats and acheivements for some extra replay and youv'e got a solid game.

As for the negatives... it's pretty obvious from the trailer. The humor is mired deeply in 90s Newgrounds humor, where yelling that you're in pain counts as humor, though there's still a few parts that are genuinely funny. The graphics are also what you'd expect from a 90s flash game.

author: {'steamid': '76561197967507597', 'num_games_owned': 5656, 'num_reviews': 29, 'playtime_forever': 400, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 400, 'last_played': 1548611207}
review:
I thought it was time to start going through my 5000+ game Steam backlog I accumlated over the past 14 or so years, so I began at random with No Time to Explain. (I seem to have both this game and the original in my library)

No Time to Explain is a pretty basic puzzle-platformer. It looks and plays like an early 2000 flash game, which it may or may not have initially been. You controller a little man who has a gun that he must use to essentially rocket-jump himself to the end of the stage avoiding various hazards like lava and spikes. Each stage is about 30 seconds long with about 5-10 stages per chapter and a boss at the end of each chapter. 

There are no enemies in the game aside from bosses but their are a few different weapons which change the way you traverse throughout the level. I really liked the different weapons as they change up the game quite a bit, although I do wish their were a few more as a lot of the levels revert back to your basic laser weapon which kind of gets stale. 

Aside from the basic gameplay loop mentined above, the game also has a few hidden "hats" throughout the game that can be discovered. Although the hats do not change the game at all and are just cosmetic in nature, they do add a nice little challenge for a completionist like myself.

Overall the game is pretty basic and not very long. I am not a big fan of the artstyle or humor, but it plays well and I quite liked the gameplay loop. I most certainly would not recommend the game at its current price of $16.99 Canadian and I probably got this game in a bundle, but at its regularly discount price of a dollar or two it is definitely worth checking out.
