author: {'steamid': '76561198353304201', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 25, 'playtime_forever': 163, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 127, 'last_played': 1552369917}
review:
I remember discovering this game when Markiplier played it. I saw that video again, wondered where the game was at, found it on Steam, and beat it in four sessions.

Worth. Every. Second.

10/10, f*cking hilarious and amazing game, will definitely play again.

author: {'steamid': '76561198117885332', 'num_games_owned': 683, 'num_reviews': 50, 'playtime_forever': 329, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 329, 'last_played': 1544485666}
review:
No Time To Explain is an old flash game created by tinyBuild, in which you play as a dude in a journey to save his many alternate universe selves from gigantic monsters.  NTTE is, in a single word, dated.  However unlike Super Meat Boy which has aged like wine, NTTE has started to mold and stiffen up in the years since it was relevent.

Firstly, the controls feel awkward.  NTTE demands rather precise, flowing, quick movements in order to control the gigantic lazer that propels you through each level.  However the lazer itself feels very sticky and finnicky, since the camera and player move independently of each other.  So if you need to keep the mouse near the player in order to minimize the distance it'll shift due to the screen moving, but this sets the player up to slip and screw up their boost.  Not to mention that in a later section, the lazer is replaced with a magnet-like ability.  You instead of finnicking your way through levels with a lazer, you need to guess and hope that you're launching yourself correctly while the curosr is arbitrarily limited to a certain distance away.

The levels don't fair much better either.  They're either rudimentary - as in a single spike-lined corridor is the only obstacle - or frustrating.  While none are infuriating, it feels as if whoever designed the levels had very little experience.  As of writing this review - having just beaten the game - I have no stand out memories of any individual level.  It's all become a blur.  The bosses fall prey to the same issues.  They're either hilariously simple or frustratingly obtuse.  I was stuck for nearly 15 minutes on the drillmole boss before I realized you needed to shoot it's head - not it's weak spot - when it's doing a specific attack, from a specific distance.  While they're interesting just to see, I can't say I enjoyed any of them.

Graphically and musically the game hasn't held up too well, but there's still some appeal to it.  It has a very "Newgrounds" style, and you can tell it was made by a couple of dudes having fun.  I'd say that's arguably the best part of the game.  It has a sense of intimacy and fun that many modern games don't capture, and it's almost like a kid you new from school is showing off his newest little pet game.

And for the achievement hunters, I'd say don't bother trying to 100%.  The game has a few achivements, most of which are filler or boring.  It's doable, but it isn't fun.

This game is a "youtube game".  It's a lot more fun to sit back and watch someone else play it, than it is to actually sit down and go through it.  Were I to put my feelings into a number, I'd give NTTE a 5/10 but the pricetag prevents me from recommending it.  If it goes on sale for $5, and you want some Newgrounds nostalgia I'd say go ahead and buy it.  To everyone else, if you're really interested in NTTE just watch a Let's Play.

review:
Il gioco Ã¨ stupendo nonostante sia vecchiotto ma con la versione remastered sembra quasi che sia uscito non piu' di qualche mese fa.
Purtroppo il tempo che bisogna impiegare per finire la storia non Ã¨ molto vista la rapida successione degli eventi, tuttavia preferisco molto un gioco in cui avvengono moltissimi fatti uno dopo l'altro (ovviamente in rapida successione) piuttosto che giochi in cui ogni 2 ore succede qualcosa.
Il gioco risulta molto divertente e se uno ha voglia puo' divertirsi a finire i nuovi achivement di cui alcuni molto strani.

author: {'steamid': '76561197980949132', 'num_games_owned': 439, 'num_reviews': 222, 'playtime_forever': 37, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 37, 'last_played': 1520806516}
review:
Enjoyable platformer with interesting mechanics and boss fights. The dialog and goofy dancing of the character are what really get me and make me continually chuckle. The controls can feel a bit sluggish at times which can be frustrating at times because the game require precision movements. The game is definitely "die" and error. 

I'm not sure how long the game is as I haven't beaten it yet but I'm guessing no more than 4 hours. Get it on sale for ~ $8 and i'd say you got a good deal.

You can watch my Let's Play footage of the game over on my  [url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=a8AoXpM5Xc0&list=PL0q93Rkkmx_sEjdOzmKPYbtXW2V9yJ5PL]YouTube Channel[/url] !

review:
No Time To Explain Remastered is a very casual fun game. 
I could even don't do a review of it, because I do not have time to explain (ahah!)

The game is simple, is visually very basic, but believe me the game is not easy, feels weird to play. I do not know if is because I play on keyboard and mouse or if the controls are effective clunky.
Anyway, the game is crazy fun and I believe you all enjoy if you like platform style games of the genre.

author: {'steamid': '76561198027267313', 'num_games_owned': 1838, 'num_reviews': 4460, 'playtime_forever': 263, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 263, 'last_played': 1643041367}
review:
Tags: Platformer
Additional Tags: Delete Local Content & Remove from Library

TLDR: Small rage platformer with spikes and small margins for precision navigation. Gimmicky gun/flinger mechanic makes platforming and combat a chore.

This is a series of very short corridors. You have infinite lives and the levels are easily  bruteforced since progress is not reset. It reminded me a bit of Life Goes On for that reason. It also had that super meatboy oriented gameplay. With focus on dying. The boss fights in particular were annoying since you were given limited lives and ofen had to aim weapons at bosses while managing the fact that you are being flung around as a result. Often in line of fire of the boss or in spikes.

Conclusion: Altogether this has a nice tone and sets its levels nicely but the gimmicky core gameplay makes it just an inferior twist on momentum management with a finnicky lunar lander feel. Not really worth returning to past a few short giggle play sessions. If you really must play those small bite sized difficult levels. Then play 10 Second NinjaX which at least gives you solid controls and a slicker engine to do it in. Removed No Time to Explain Remastered permanently for declutter.
https://store.steampowered.com/app/435790/10_Second_Ninja_X/
https://store.steampowered.com/app/40800/Super_Meat_Boy/
https://store.steampowered.com/app/250050/Life_Goes_On_Done_to_Death/

author: {'steamid': '76561198061571355', 'num_games_owned': 292, 'num_reviews': 12, 'playtime_forever': 895, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 890, 'last_played': 1601611545}
review:
After many attempts I have finally acquired the last achievement and can post my review!

I. Love. This. Game.

I (un?)fortunately didn't get to play it prior to the remastering, but I can say that I followed the game a little since its announcement on Kickstarter.  I loved the humor and the concept and am glad to say that it delivers on that front.

No Time to Explain is a short puzzle-platformer with a heavy splash of humor.  The puzzles don't become exceedingly hard, but they do challenge you to think differently as you progress from universe to universe.  Some puzzles require far more precision than others, but don't worry because in the event of failure you pick back up at your last known "okay position" (i.e. standing on solid ground).  This makes the game rather forgiving.

If you're looking for something humourous with a little puzzle and action sequences this game is for you.  If you're looking for a puzzle game with increasingly complex puzzles or for an action platformer you might want to pass this one up.

PS: My only gripe is that it took tinyBuild SO LONG to finally release the soundtrack for the Remastered Edition.  I've been using a bootleg version ripped from the Unity files for quite a while now, and am glad that I can purchase an official DLC with official names for tracks (as well as bonus tracks :D ).

author: {'steamid': '76561198054674251', 'num_games_owned': 660, 'num_reviews': 338, 'playtime_forever': 21, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 21, 'last_played': 1535458980}
review:
The controls are infuriating. You cannot even remap the jump to A. Albeit, the jump isn't super useful, but to have the reminder pop up everytime you reflexively press A to jump--like in any normal platforming game--is a pain. The game's main mode of platforming is the weapon you have. At first, it's an obvious reference to the old "imma firin ma lazar" meme from 15 years back, the second is a shotgun, and I only assume that each subsequent world delivers a new weapon-platformer. I don't know because I do not feel compelled in any way to continue playing.

The levels themselves, in the first two worlds I played, are uninspired. Spike-walled and plain. The first world at least changes the themes a bit, but the developers gave up on the second world, apparently "water" was enough.

Maybe this game was fun when it was released, but honestly, with the plethora of great platformers available, I wouldn't recommend buying this unless you're looking for a nostalgia kick.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011511137', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 38, 'playtime_forever': 174, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 174, 'last_played': 1535158103}
review:
There were some fun levels in this game, but I felt they were far and few between. Most of the levels were frustrating, needing precision movement with imprecise controls. 

The humor also just didn't do it for me. I chuckled a few times, but found myself getting annoyed with the same few lines repeated over and over as I tried to finish a level. It's just not my brand of humor.

I certainly wouldn't pay full price for this game, but it was a halfway entertaining way to spend a couple hours.

author: {'steamid': '76561198002112565', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1534713683}
review:
I enjoyed this game actually but please read the review as to why i don't recommend it.

The game is just a basic puzzle game made in flash that takes around 2-2.5 hours to finish in shortest time span possible to finish it as a first time player.(rest depends on your level of expertise in puzzle genre).I am not good with them so it took me longer.

The game is simple.You have a beam laser you use to pass obstacles and enter wormholes to finish levels.Gameplay changes in certain chapters where you obtain different weapons and characters.Football players blast gun makes you fly in an arc trajectory,straitjacket flies opposite direction of your aim and acts like a slingshot,aborted fetus frog is the same as straitjacket except with the ability to sticks to the walls,Hipster beam has ink and shows invisible platforms and last one is a combination of regular beam and football players blast gun.

Levels are very forgiving and it starts you from the place you died.There are no lives and it makes the game feel lacking.
Difficulty curve is non-existent.Sometimes,first or second levels of the chapters are ridiculous and because the controls are clunky you just randomly try until you get to do it.Asylum level one is a good example of that.Perhaps thats why you have infinite lives and it is not enjoyable.

The music is ok,nothing noteworthy.It serves only as background noise.Story is non-existent and the humor is for manchildren that still roams NG.com and watches video game parodies.I did genuienly laugh at a few jokes.(mispronounced diabetes joke and the part where developers mock hipsters that think video games are art....I know...The manchildren infected me...)
Boss fights were quite fun actually and i enjoyed fighting them more than the rest of the game itself and that says something about the game.

VERDICT:I enjoyed this game and it's enjoyable for what it is meant to be.A short game to have fun but i think the gameplay is flawed and lacks substance for a game that I would buy.I just can't see myself buying this game for it's price.If thats what you are looking for i can recommend it otherwise do not buy this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198249747386', 'num_games_owned': 331, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 214, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 95, 'last_played': 1613359196}
review:
There's No Time To Explain Why, But Don't. Buy. This. Game.

Wait, yes, there is! But I need to be quick. The game is:
-Boring
-Repetitive
-Tedious
-There is an extreme variability in difficulty across the levels
-Poor controls
-It's more about your luck and patiently (stupidly?) repeating a level a dozen times until you finally hit the right spot to land on. Then rinse and repeat, on ugly, simple, repetitive and boring maps.
-Your whining future self gets boring pretty quickly at every respawn (like 10000 of them).
-You haven't even become comfortable with the mechanics when, without an explanation, a radically new one is introduced - only for it to disappear after a few levels. When the game is not the Most. Boring. Game. Ever., these unexplained, annoying surprises that make you wonder even more whether the devs are just messing with you, or flat out insane, are what keep you from falling into a come from boredom.

-You haven't even become comfortable with the mechanics when, without an explanation, a radically new one is introduced - only for it to disappear after a few levels. When the game is not the Most. Boring. Game. Ever., these unexplained, annoying surprises that make you wonder even more whether the devs are just messing with you, or flat out insane, are what keep you from falling into a come from boredom.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009474997', 'num_games_owned': 2217, 'num_reviews': 1072, 'playtime_forever': 570, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 570, 'last_played': 1532453817}
review:
a Really fun and comedic game , you will really enjoy this one, but not at it's full price, it is over priced i think, this game isnt that long and really doesnt offer that much to make that price tag worth it in my opinion.

The game itself is quite enjoyable and even funny. It is a side scroller where you move from left to right to get through the campaign level, the game does get a bit harder as you reach higher levels but they are still doable.  The gameplay for this type of game is very decently done and you really do enjoy the game , unless this is not your type of game that is. The graphics arent that special but they were neatly done and implemented , fitting well with the game. The story may not be that deep but we have one and we follow it. The controls are fairly simple once you got used to them, its said that a controller is best for this game. All in all if you get this game in a bundle or on sale sure it is worth it.

author: {'steamid': '76561198054246483', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 4, 'playtime_forever': 137, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 137, 'last_played': 1529606889}
review: It's super fun for the first few levels but then instead of adding guns the developer decided to add all new mechanics that2 mae the game tedious to play. The boss fights also get progressively worse. Instead of making them more difficult the developer just made them last longer so it begins to feel like a chore to play. Long boss fights are fine but when the boss only does the same three moves the entire fight it's too much.

author: {'steamid': '76561198166645513', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 101, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 101, 'last_played': 1528468177}
review:
[h1][i]Pas le temps de faire un jeu remasterisÃ©.[/i][/h1]

[i]Wah ! Ce jeu est gÃ©nial ! Il a tellement d'humour Ã  se prendre au second degrÃ© ! Quelle autodÃ©rision !"[/i] TA GUEULE. L'autodÃ©rision n'est pas une excuse pour faire un mauvais jeu.

HonnÃªtement, je n'ai apprÃ©ciÃ© le jeu que les dix premiÃ¨res minutes. AprÃ¨s c'est n'importe quoi. Le titre base toute sa justification sur le fait qu'il n'y a pas de justification. Cette idÃ©e aurait pu Ãªtre la source d'un trÃ¨s bon titre, malheureusement c'est ce qu'on appelle dans le milieu... de la merde. Le jeu aurait clairement dÃ» rester un jeu flash.

26k $ de budget. A l'Ã©chelle de l'Ã©conomie vidÃ©o-ludique, c'est trÃ¨s peu. Et pourtant, une quantitÃ© immense de dÃ©veloppeurs ont fait bien mieux avec beaucoup moins. Comme quoi le manque de budget n'est pas une excuse non plus.

Bon, il est temps de passer au pourquoi de mon crachat salÃ© sur ce jeu.

Tout d'abord, le prix. 15â‚¬. Pour un jeu flash remasterisÃ©. Bon. Ensuite, le jeu est tout bonnement injouable. Apparemment les devs ont assez d'humour pour faire la blague de ne pas mettre un menu de paramÃ¨tres. Navrant. Et dans la lignÃ©e du "rien n'est expliquÃ©", AH BAH VOUS VOUS DOUTEZ BIEN, les mÃ©caniques ne disposent mÃªme pas d'un tuto.
D'habitude je mettrais un screenshot en plein milieu de mon Ã©valuation pour l'aÃ©rer un peu, mais dans le cas actuel cela ne ferait qu'augmenter le taux de malaise. Parce que oui, le jeu s'offre en plus le luxe d'Ãªtre moche. Certes il aurait pu l'Ãªtre encore plus, mais il l'est dÃ©jÃ  bien. Et vous l'aurez au plus profond de vous devinÃ©, j'en suis certain, ces graphismes dignes d'[i]E.T.[/i] sur Atari sont accompagnÃ©s d'une bande son d'une qualitÃ© exceptionnelle. [i]*Rires*[/i]. Si l'on considÃ¨re qu'enregistrer des sons et les amplifier et les saturer c'est considÃ©rÃ© comme de la crÃ©ation de bande sonore.

Ce qui m'ennuie dans tout Ã§a, c'est que le jeu avait l'air bien. Je l'ai achetÃ© (en soldes quand mÃªme, faut pas dÃ©conner) de bonne volontÃ©, avec l'intention de passer un bon moment et de publier une Ã©valuation positive. Eh bah en fait non. Je ne dirais pas que tout dans ce jeu est Ã  jeter, mais en fait si.

Note : 8/20

review:
I am you from the future! No time to explain! Follow me to the- OH CHRIST!!!
 I would definetly recommend this game (when it's on sale) It's very entertaining and humorous and, unlike alot of games, it is simple. Use your raygun as a booster to move throughout timelines and try to save the future! I wouldn't pay $15 dollars for it, but it's definitly a great game to get on sale!

author: {'steamid': '76561198019315410', 'num_games_owned': 631, 'num_reviews': 73, 'playtime_forever': 128, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 128, 'last_played': 1527313450}
review:
My friends don't like platformers as much, which is a shame because I personally really enjoyed this. It's entirely puzzle platforming, stuff like "how do I get myself over there" instead of "oh no dodge lasers and return fire." The game lives up to its name, there really is no time to explain. New mechanics are introduced wordlessly, explained only through clever level design that encourages the player to discover what they can do with the new mechanic, and flawlessly tests the player's knowledge later for just long enough to stay fun. Cosmetic collectables litter the levels to provide an optional challenge that usually requires total mastery of the new mechanic. The hats range from amazing to meh, and I'm personally not a fan of the ones that replace your head entirely, but they're all fun to acquire and enjoy having in your collection, even if you never use them.

Don't be like me and forget about this game for a year or else you'll forget core mechanics like [spoiler]you get more height by walking off an edge while shooting down instead of jumping first.[/spoiler]

author: {'steamid': '76561198138337568', 'num_games_owned': 110, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 32, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 32, 'last_played': 1508469259}
review:
At first I had high hopes for this game seeing how it had decent humour and interesting game mechanics but after about 20-30 minutes it just gts repetitive and boring, feeling like the developers just kinda streched out the game for more play time. Eben though I got the game for free I just see no interest in playing it. If you wanna buy it Buy it on a big sale so you dont have to spend the 17 D O L L A R S for a flash game thats not even fun. 

   In expection to this the developers (TinyBuild) Have made some other, very fun games like Speedrunners, Punch Club, and Hello Neighbour so if you like to support the developers you can get those games.

author: {'steamid': '76561198093919303', 'num_games_owned': 278, 'num_reviews': 48, 'playtime_forever': 158, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 158, 'last_played': 1519002213}
review:
What a cute little indie game. With many indie games, there's this need to feel like it's contributing something novel to gaming in general. I don't get that feel with No Time To Explain. Instead, it's just a quirky platformer that, admittedly, feels like a revamped online game (which is probably appropriate, since it is.) It took me two hours to complete, though there were many hats that I could have found in the various worlds; I probably found 50% of them.

Let's start off with the mechanics. This is both the best and most frustrating part of the game: your character moves extremely slowly and your jump is quite frankly pathetic, but the LASER CANNON more than makes up for the both of them. The only issue on that front is that the cannon is fairly hard to control. I played this game with a gamepad, and I feel like that was probably the right choice. A keyboard would just be weird, and probably even worse control-wise.

Next up is story. The story of this game is extremely chaotic, up till and including the reveal of the main villain. The main character changes multiple times, and your movement options change as well. There was a level that just felt shoehorned in because the devs thought it was a good idea. Granted, it was, but it did feel slightly out of place.

The soundtrack was appropriate. Different boss and world music that didn't get too repetitive, and faded into the background nicely. If anything, it highlighted the "online game"  aspect just due to its somewhat basic electronic groove that we all know from games like super meat boy, electronic super joy, etc.

Finally the art. Not great, not bad either. Again, a very blatant reminder of the whole online game thing, with insane explosions and blood loss.

Ultimately, it was good, but not fantastic. When I looked back at the actual price/what I payed for it, I was slightly shocked; No Time To Explain is, in my opinion, very definitely overpriced at $15. At 50% off, it's still a bit too much, but there's a decent chance that I'm just saying that because I'm pretty cheap. Go ahead and buy it if you like interesting platformers, or if you have any nostalgia for those early 2000's online platformers.

review: Well then I'll actually explain it to you: You have a crazy powerful laser weapon that pushes you the opposite direction when you fire.  Then...well, lots of stuff happens, involving you from the future...and it just kind of picks up from there.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011987255', 'num_games_owned': 264, 'num_reviews': 67, 'playtime_forever': 74, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1525929396}
review:
For a flash game redone in Unity, it's not bad. The humor wears off quickly but the gameplay is solid. Levels quickly get more challening till you finally reach the "hard-core" platformer level. The only thing I dislike is how boss fights have limited lives, whereas the rest of the game you simply respawn at the last point where you landed safely. It makes boss fights unnecessarily frustrating.

For the price though, and what it is, you can't go wrong here.

author: {'steamid': '76561198090438425', 'num_games_owned': 276, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 164, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 164, 'last_played': 1515662966}
review:
Stiff controls. After few stages, repetative level design only with different mechanics. I know this game was not made in a huge studio and a lot of people using a big budget, but I know some cheaper games than this one that have better voice acting, better sound quality and better visuals. Some bosses are way to easy, some bosses are unreasonably hard. Last boss is horribly done. There are a bunch of exploits in the game that devs weren't thinking about. Not worth the money at all.

SPOILERS:
The only thing I found amusing is the ink levels where the pixelated guy tells you reasons why games are art. You need to find platforms using black ink instead of the laser, neat idea.

review:
Non ho trovato il gioco molto divertente. Per quanto sia un platform puro, in cui le modalitÃ  per superare lo stage vari in base all'arma che utilizziamo in ogni universo, ho trovato il gioco (che ho interrotto ad una certa) abbastanza frustrante.
Non consiglio l'acquisto a meno che non cerchiate una di quelle sfide dove bisogna fare i salti, alle volte, al millimetro. Per me questo non Ã¨ sinonimo di divertimento.

author: {'steamid': '76561198135528601', 'num_games_owned': 136, 'num_reviews': 17, 'playtime_forever': 2783, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 864, 'last_played': 1611849867}
review:
Quote "Physics, nuff' said" ~Myself. <- TL:DR


      Well, physics are one of the funnest game mechanics, trying to strategize while adjusting to a new mechanic of momentum makes exploring extremely fun. My only problem is that the level size is fairly small even though giant mega levels COULD be made. I feel like less levels that are bigger > a lot of short levels.
      
      Also the steedrun achievment is a little bit too difficult imo.

review:
HATE the controls.

I can't stand the fact that the right stick aims and shoots and then you still have the RT be shoot as well?  Seriously, let me set it so that I can aim with the stick and shoot with RT.  Why even have the RT button to shoot if the right stick also shoots?

Other than that, the game is kind of fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198198006519', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 9, 'playtime_forever': 282, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 282, 'last_played': 1513498582}
review:
Interessanter Platformer mit manchmal merkwÃ¼rdiger aber dennoch innovativer Fortbewegung. Die Steuerung klappt mit einem Gamepad vermutlich besser als mit Tastatur und Maus. Mit Maus verschwand gerne das Fadenkreuz am Bildrand und ich musste mich neu orientieren. AuflÃ¶sung ist 720p. Nur als Info fÃ¼r alle, die mindestens 1080p erwarten. Das spielt aber letztlich keine Rolle. Die Grafik ist hÃ¼bsch anzusehen und es gibt eine lustige Story mit vielen Gags. Die Musik ist abwechselungsreich, angenehm und passend. Das Spiel ist sehr liebevoll gemacht und empfehlenswert es mal zu spielen. Nur 6 Prozent aller Besitzer des Spiels haben es durchgespielt. Na, das kann ja so nicht bleiben. ^^

Spielzeit liegt je nach KÃ¶nnen bei 2-6h. Wobei man auch gerne ab und zu steckenbleiben kann und erstmal einen "LÃ¶sungsweg" finden muss.

author: {'steamid': '76561198064354254', 'num_games_owned': 280, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 153, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1513208828}
review: No Time To Explain is a very random and fun indie game about time traveling and laserbeams. I would say it's worth the money even at full price, but keep in mind that the game isn't that long. It focuses on fun gameplay and story, and it succeeds well with this goal. It isn't the best game I've played for it's price tag though, so wait for sale if you're unsure.

author: {'steamid': '76561198071291943', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 25, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 25, 'last_played': 1512904498}
review: For me it's simple - platformer where you are using weapon recoil to beat levels. I'm not kinda person who likes spend much time in these type of games, where I need to try and try to beat some point trying to master a sequence on some level. I'm still recommending this game as this is something for people who like platformer with non-linear approach for beating the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198083994096', 'num_games_owned': 1271, 'num_reviews': 23, 'playtime_forever': 59, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 59, 'last_played': 1512226168}
review:
Well, seem most of the people around here likes the game, and I have hard time understanding why.

The game is hard, but it is so, not because it is actually hard but because the controls are insane and level desing expects you to be "hair precise". And when you are not you die. That is one of the things thing I actually hate here. But that is not enough, when you die, you just respawn. Or you go one "step" back and respawn there, when a "boss" is involved. That is another thing I really hate. Should not this game be hard? Or did I missed something? This looks more like "master the control so precisely so you can finish the level while blind and with only our off-hand". That is another (and)  a bit worse verison of what I stated earlier that I hate. Also, it tries to be funny, but when I see or hear the same joke over and over again, while I am trying to learn to control the game, it just gets boring, and in fact, even though it was ment to be funny and maybe sometimes even was few first times, it gets anoying realy realy soon and in the end it makes things even worse.

So, I unerstand, that some people are in it for the challenge of beating something impossible or whatever, even though I do not really undertand why, but if you are that kind of person, just treat this a positive review. But for me it feels like a total waste of time. And yes. I know I am speaking about time waster here.

So, in the end, I think this really is not a game for me, and if I didn't get it as part of some low cost bundle somewhere, I would be requesting refund right away, because the price really does seems insane to me more than the controlls

author: {'steamid': '76561198278697384', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 15, 'playtime_forever': 350, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 350, 'last_played': 1511951582}
review:
Videojuego de plataformas con cierto parecido a los antiguos del gÃ©nero pero aprovechando la versatilidad de tener un ratÃ³n en la mano para ofrecer una propuesta algo diferente.

El apartado grÃ¡fico no es la gran cosa pero cumple para ser un juego de este gÃ©nero, ademÃ¡s de hacer los enfrentamientos finales algo mÃ¡s desenfadados.

La duraciÃ³n es bastante corta ademÃ¡s de que en cuanto a rejugabilidad yo no le doy demasiadas esperanzas, pues he completado el juego y conseguido todos los coleccionables en unas cuatro horas, ademÃ¡s de completar algunos logros por mero gusto lo que solo ha subido una hora de duraciÃ³n al tÃ­tulo. En cinco horas ya he visto todo lo que ofrece y he rejugado muchos niveles, ademÃ¡s de haberme quedado con la impresiÃ³n de que no lo voy a volver a tocar por esto mismo, asÃ­ que estamos hablando de un juego realmente corto.

Hay que hablar tambiÃ©n de la campaÃ±a, pues ha dejado la historia de lado para directamente meternos en la aventura sin preocuparnos por absolutamente nada mÃ¡s, mientras vamos avanzado vemos que realmente sÃ­ que hay una trama, pero como los mismo creadores del juego sabÃ­an, es una mierda y no tiene relevancia alguna, asÃ­ que la Ãºnica funciÃ³n es tener una excusa para hacernos recorrer los diferentes niveles por los que vamos pasando. Al menos los toques de humor son algo que le da cierta simpatÃ­a a lo poco de trama que vamos viendo al avanzar.

Recomiendo probar el juego pues realmente es muy entretenido, eso sÃ­, no merece lo que vale pues es demasiado corto, pero si lo consiguen como parte de un Bundle es una compra asegurada.

author: {'steamid': '76561198032632033', 'num_games_owned': 247, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 97, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 97, 'last_played': 1511703353}
review:
No Time To Explain ist definitiv witzig, obwohl der Schwierigkeitsgrad nicht immer zum Lachen war. 

Ab einer bestimmten Stelle wird eine neue "Mechanik" eingefÃ¼hrt, welche den Spielfluss - zumindest fÃ¼r mich - fast ganz zum Erliegen gebracht hat.

Wer jedoch Freude an schweren 2D-Platformern hat und auch mit dem Humor von No Time To Explain etwas anfangen kann, sollte dem Spiel unbedingt eine Chance geben. Zumal man bei dem Preis (zurzeit 3,74â‚¬) fast nichts falsch machen kann.

Wertung: 7/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198243477348', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 57, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 57, 'last_played': 1512187983}
review:
Do not play this game. This game is a failed attempt at a humorous and challenging platformer. allow me to explain, I have time:
1. The art and sound- this game simply looks like a newgrounds cartoon. which is acceptable for a video, (as that kind of animation does require a lot of effort) but in a game like this each character only really needs max 30 different frames of animation, so the characters just look incredibly lazy. throw into the mix that just about every part of the backgrounds and levels are just as simple, the end game just looks very bare bones, which would be acceptable under other cirmustances, e.g. undertale is a very charming game with a simple art style, however the character and background design in No Time To Explain is not nearly as charming. it just looks like a 2-minute youtube short. the musical score is very repeditive and forgetable and the sound of the primary lazer weapon sounds like my speakers are dying.

2. "Humor"- as previously mentioned, this game looks like a youtube short made by ameteur animators, and writing matches quite well. all of the humor in this game thus far has just been a character constantly shouting in pain as they are being eaten by some kind of monster. this becomes even more annoying when you constantly die, causing you to listen to the SAME ANNOYING LINES OVER AND OVER! the voice acting itself is very reminscent of some talentless and cringy letsplayer putting on voices.

3. gameplay- i'll admit i haven't played much of this, (i tried but i just hated it so much i couldnt continue) but from what ive experienced so far, the entire game is just plaforming and boss fights. (i dont even think there are non boss enemies in this) the platforming is much like that of super meat boy. the gimmick however, is that your player-character cannot jump more than like, 2 pixels on screen, so you have to rocket around with a variety of weapons, primarily a laser cannon. the physics of the character and the gun are way too fast and the controls are much too floaty, making the game a lot more frustrating than challenging. The boss fights take away the one saving grace from the plaforming because now- instead of infinite lives- you have three. and the problem is that 90% of player death can be put down to the characters own weapon, which incidentally seems to do pretty much no damage to the enemy, because its putting all of its effort into pushing you into spikes everytime you shoot it. 

I got this game in humble bundle with speedrunners. speedrunners is actually good. get that instead.

3/5

author: {'steamid': '76561198080319088', 'num_games_owned': 564, 'num_reviews': 59, 'playtime_forever': 73, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 73, 'last_played': 1505737293}
review:
I bought the game, because it was so highly advertised during the GDQ's and I expected a high quality game for a high quality event. Unfortunately it was just like any other indie game.

The Commentary and Humour is extremely forced and immature. It seems like they wanted to say ''Fukc'' as often as possible, just for the sake of saying it and 'being funny'.  But thats just like my opinion, man, so no deduction for the humour.

The gameplay itself is just bland and boring. You're waiting for the game to get started, but it keeps intoducing gameplay and new characters, so you never really get to a point where you can enjoy it. It much moreso seems like a demo, full of ''look what i managed to programm''-stuff from the devs, packed into one game, hold together by ducttape.
That CAN work, see Cuphead, and in this case it clearly didn't, one example for that :
The controls arenÂ´t tight enough for a touhou section. (You're flying with a JetPack and get into a bullethell-esk Level)
And if you die, guess what, you have to play the whole level again, which can be up to 4 minutes long + watch the cringy unskipable intro every time.
Thats another huge downside : Unskipable intros. I mean, even if you enjoy the humour you must agree that the cutscenes are annoying if you have to watch them several times.

And my last complaint : It is absolutly overpriced. I don't remember where I got the game from, but I'm a 100% sure that I didn't spend 15$ on this. You can buy Skyrim, 15 bundles, a humble bundle monthly with 3+ top tier games  or anything else in the same price range and you'll be happier with that than with this. I garuantee.

author: {'steamid': '76561198271433195', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 6, 'playtime_forever': 60, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 60, 'last_played': 1499625883}
review: TinyBuild seemed to be scraping at the bottom of the barrel with this game. It rapidly declined in the entertainment derived from it as it slowly progressed toward tediousness. There is a line drawn between a challenge and a long-drawn story and this game simply crossed the line.

review: No Time to Explain is a sidescrolling platformer/shooter concerning time paradoxes and giant laser guns in an easily digestable, even humorous game. The reveal of new mechanics and their relation to the story are paced really well and i was able to beat the game in a matter of a few hours. It presents its ideas organically and explicity. Overall, this game is great and well worth its cost.

author: {'steamid': '76561198063841980', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 1, 'playtime_forever': 343, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 343, 'last_played': 1504861034}
review:
My GOD I hate this game.

To keep it short and sweet:

[b]Pros:[/b]
[list]
    [*]The humor is good, for the most part. I laughed at a few of the jokes, which is more than most games can offer.
    [*]The music has its moments, but for the most part it's passable at best.
[/list]

[b]Cons:[/b]
[list]
    [*]The platforming gimmick isn't fun, it's frustrating. You never feel like you're really in control of your character, sometimes you can do what seems to be the exact same movement but get wildly different results.
    [*]The art is bland. Most of the tilesets are basic and the world feels flat. Some assets [spoiler] The gravity spin tiles in the candy world[/spoiler] feel out of place.
    [*]The level design is boring and the difficulty curve is like a rollercoaster. Most of the time, levels felt like a jumble of objects instead of a 'real' place, for lack of a better word.
[/list]

Overall, this game is mediocre/below average. I wouldn't suggest it, sale or not.

author: {'steamid': '76561197992056243', 'num_games_owned': 1204, 'num_reviews': 72, 'playtime_forever': 140, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 140, 'last_played': 1504364822}
review:
Here's my review so far with 2.5 Hours. This game is hilarious. I love the voice and dialogue within this game. However, this game is HARD. Not sure how I'm going to get passed the stage I'm at. Great with gamepad, runs smooth, decent graphics/art. Haven't got a single Achievement yet, there's 9 of them. All in all, I recommend this game for anyone looking for something challenging and different.

Also about other people's reviews, $16.99 is a bit steep for sure. Didn't realize this was originally a Flash Game, and like them I too got it from Humble Bundle. Still a good game. Some levels you're going to play over and over, but you learn some tricks and the do's and dont's. So to the one guy saying very poor mechanics and controls, I beg to differ. You just didn't understand how to use it and work with it, and how each level is meant to be beat.

review:
It's a reverse jetpack mechanic, in that you shoot a gun and move the oposite way. On some platforming levels, if you keep it fixed and aimed at the right angle you've got yourself a flappy bird game.
I tried both controller and mouse but found this game frustrating and gave up, but some people may like it.

author: {'steamid': '76561197969749884', 'num_games_owned': 2459, 'num_reviews': 1422, 'playtime_forever': 2526, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 2526, 'last_played': 1503728292}
review:
No Time To Explain is the remake of a free browser flash game based on attraction as well as repulsion physics to make it through the corresponding levels. It is really minimalistic in gameplay terms, although it features half a dozen different worlds with just as many different specials versions of the physics gun you're using to make it out alive.

The art design fits the game and at times it feels like south park on steroids. Which is a good thing in my book.

All in all, it's a nice little gem for doing some missions inbetween. It's definitely not worth the asking price though and should only be picked up as part of a bundle or on sale.

review: I really wanted to like this game, It looked fun and funny and challenging. I played through the entire first section of the game which for the most part I enjoyed. Smart ideas, cool level design, but very difficult controls. After the first segment ii only got worse, they introduce a new mechanic that is so hard to control the game virtually becomes unplayable. I am not just complaning because the game was too hard to beat. Ther is a diference between challenging and teadious. half of the time you rely on luck more than skill to pass levels and that is not fun for me. I played dark souls, i know hard diffuculties but this was just painful. I wanted to like this game so much but it fell so short.

review:

author: {'steamid': '76561198010155821', 'num_games_owned': 791, 'num_reviews': 100, 'playtime_forever': 430, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 430, 'last_played': 1501454157}
review:
[h1] What the f*** ?? [/h1]

Those words precise crossed my mind as I watched gigantic crab, holding a guy spraying blood over half the screen, run away from another person flying on a laser beam fired from a gun. That was barely a developer introduction panel. It sets the tone for the rest of the game perfectly as it is full of ridicullous and absurd humour. If you enjoyed levels of absurd present in Kung Fury or ASDF movies you should probably find yourself at home with this game.

[b] Time To Explain [/b]
As the game progresses what seemed nothing less than a silly gimmick at the first glance gradually truns out to be fairly solid platformer. Once I started focusing more on game mechanics I enjoyed the variety perhaps not so much in the level desing as in means of completing it. Primary mechanic is flying on a laser beam but game continues to add new elements (such as shotgun leaping and a sidescroller shooter sequence) at a pace sufficent for game to stay fresh and interesting throughout its course.

The game is rather short but completion time as with every platformer varies greatly on individual skill. No Time To Explain doesn't require masochistic joys of e.g. Super Meat Boy for its completion. Hardcore platformer enthusiast should try complete achievements, with extra conditions they apply, game can be quite a challenge. Alluring feature for some might be the local co-op which can turn the game into a "couch" title to play with your firends. Also No Time To Explain includes level editor with full workshop support which can increase game's lifespan greatly.

This title definitely isn't for everyone but it can make for a good laugh and enjoyable if a little cranky platformer.

author: {'steamid': '76561198110856032', 'num_games_owned': 400, 'num_reviews': 53, 'playtime_forever': 428, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 403, 'last_played': 1588084979}
review: Although "Remastered" is in the title, it still looks like a resized flash game from Newgrounds. But, [b]BUT[/b], it's witty, it's fast-paced, and an all-around good time. You're bounced around between multiple wacky, alternate universes to play as different you's and collect different hats. And if you want a goddamn challenge, then try to earn all of the Steam achievements. Those last few were some of the most difficult, rage-inducing achieves I've ever earned, and dammitall, I earned them.

author: {'steamid': '76561198137383735', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 188, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 188, 'last_played': 1501349729}
review:
This game is so good! My first impression was a browser game with no sense and stupid storyline, but after finishing it I was so surprised. Levels are very funny and you must have a bit of skill otherwise you can't finish this game beacause difficulty is pretty balanced as you advance in the game. The graphic has the classic cartoon style but for this game is perfect. But this game is not all roses, cause there are two main issues. The first is the game longevity, which is about 2 hours if you're fast and 3 hours if you're slow (like me :D), but there are also many other workshop maps that you can play. The second and most important issue are controls, which aren't perfect, especially for some characters.

CONCLUSION
I would reccomend this game to anyone who is bored and wants a funny/casual game. Trust me that it's worth it :D

game was fine until torches levels :
the difference being that if you take too many tries & die while on fire you restart the whole level.
should be a choice, since so far you restarted from last landed position.

author: {'steamid': '76561198042294733', 'num_games_owned': 2915, 'num_reviews': 5, 'playtime_forever': 434, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 397, 'last_played': 1648719675}
review:
The original release of No Time To Explain was plagued by performance issues, but thanks to this re-release (which owners of the original recieved for free), those issues have been squashed. Which is great, becasue the game itself is a ton of fun. Gleefully frustrating, completely off-the-wall wacky, brilliant soundtrack, and hey, you can eat cake while shooting lazers at dinosaurs. 

If you like platformers and games that make you laugh, then this'll be right up your alley.

author: {'steamid': '76561198047175821', 'num_games_owned': 268, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 2150, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 153, 'last_played': 1474741173}
review: I got this game for free for preordering another game or something.  I think for having Speedrunnerrs?  The game itself isn't that bad.  The graphics are something from the flash era of NewGrounds.  But that isn't inherently bad.  There is no real tutorial or any way to find help other than a quick google.  But the kicker is trying to get the game to start in the first place.  I read forum after forum thread after thread.  Then one day the thing started working.  Playing the game can be fun.  But it really isn't worth the price of admission when it takes hours to get a game to play.

author: {'steamid': '76561198139104167', 'num_games_owned': 166, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 842, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 605, 'last_played': 1663803352}
review: There's something incredible about this game, something magical, something astounding. It's sad that some are blind to it. Some say, "It's too short! 15$ for, like, 100-odd short levels? No, sir!" To that I say, "Have you played this game on mute?" The sounds in this game are like a symphony. The music adds a whole layer of replayability to the game. "Sick, Sick Mind" is one of my favorites of both this game and of all time. Just that is enough, but the dialouge is incredible. The jokes are to die for. However, a game crumbles without solid, entertaining gameplay. Sadly, there are a couple of levels and fights this game would benifit from being abolished completely, but 95% of the time, No Time To Explain aims and hits amazing, interesting gameplay. Even the story, which is supposed to be complicated, confusing and impossible to piece together is surprisingly enjoyable and deep. In short, a pros and cons list would be almost unnecessary.

review: The horrible controls are just not worth it. In the short time I've spent with this game it showed some half-decent humour and a few interesting hooks and twists with its mechanics, collectibles, and secrets. However I simply couldn't continue forcing myself to deal with the horrible controls. I got the game from a Humble Bundle so I haven't lost much, but definitely don't buy this at full price. At a 80-90% discount it might be worth a gamble if you set your expectations low, but otherwise STAY AWAY.

review:
No Time To Explain is an amazing blend of platformer and action, forcing players to plan out their route with limited time, so get re-

QUICK, THERE'S NO TIME TO EXPLAIN!

GRAB THAT GUN, SHOOT THAT GUY, HIT THE RED BUTTON, AND WIN THE GAME.

Good luck to anyone buying this game. It's... a blast.

author: {'steamid': '76561198011023031', 'num_games_owned': 516, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 1748, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 113, 'last_played': 1498801960}
review: An overpriced web browser game. Controls are attrocious. Mechanics range from difficult to use to downright awful. The game saves your last safe platform you landed on before you died, rather than the furthest platform. This means if you accidentally fall to the beginning of a level and touch ground, then die, you are stuck at the beginning again. This, paired with the poor controls makes the game infuriating for all the wrong reasons. Only reason I have this game is because I got it from a Humble Bundle. There are much better platformer games at this price. Skip this one.

author: {'steamid': '76561197996919908', 'num_games_owned': 1532, 'num_reviews': 875, 'playtime_forever': 197, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 197, 'last_played': 1496501389}
review:
[h1]Der absolute Wahnsinn! [/h1]

Ich wollte schon lange das erste Spiel von TinyBuild, "No Time To Explain Remastered" spielen, die 15 â‚¬ waren mir aber etwas zu happig. Jetzt hab ichs endlich Ã¼ber ein Humble Bundle bekommen und ich bereue nichts!

[b]Gameplay[/b]
"No Time To Explain" ist ein 2D Jump 'n' Run, welches sehr gut umgesetzt wurde und mich persÃ¶nlich auch leicht an "Super Meat Boy" erinnert. 

Schon zu Beginn des Spiels bekommen wir unseren Blaster, mit dem wir hÃ¶her springen kÃ¶nnen und ihn auch als Waffen benutzen. Umso hÃ¶her wir springen, umso besser kÃ¶nnen wir auch mit dem Blaster fliegen. Schwierig wird es, wenn wir auf Etwas schieÃŸen und dabei nicht auf den Boden stehen, denn dann fliegt man doch leicht unkontrolliert. Das Spiel ist selber in bestimmte Levelbereiche aufgesplittet, wovon jeder 1-5 Level lang ist und meistens einen Boss beinhaltet. Nach knapp 3 Stunden war ich durch, allerdings ist das Spiel nie langweilig geworden, da einfach wirklich alle 5 Minuten das Gameplay komplett auf den Kopf gedreht wurde und man sich wirklich immer mit neuen Features beschÃ¤ftigen musste. Dabei gibt das Spiel aber meistens ein einfaches Level voraus, wodurch man sich flÃ¼ssig mit der neuen Spielmechanik anfreunden kann. Und natÃ¼rlich gibt es in fast jedem Level ein Sammelobjekt, in diesem Fall sind es lustige HÃ¼te. Ich wÃ¼rde das Spiel weiterhin als recht schwer bezeichnen, insbesondere bei einem Boss saÃŸ ich lange fest. Hat man das Spiel durch, kann man sich entweder selber Level erstellen oder welche aus dem Workshop spielen. Die Community hat hier sehr viel Fantasie und KreativitÃ¤t gelassen.


[b]Story[/b]
Der Name ist Programm. Die Story ist einfach durch und genau deswegen konnten die Entwickler einfach alles mit diesem Spiel machen. StÃ¤ndig passiert irgendetwas total abgedrehtes und VerrÃ¼cktes. Irgendetwas mit Dinosauriern, dem "Ich" aus der Zukunft, dem BÃ¶sewicht, einem Rugby Spieler und irgendwelchen durchgeknallten Monstern. Das Spiel nimmt viele Klischees auf die Schippe und parodiert auch andere Spiele, so z.B. Minecraft. Aber auch die eigenen Spielszenen werden  immer wieder verarscht. Man mags kaum glauben, aber tatsÃ¤chlich folgt das Spiel einer Geschichte und es ist nicht alles nur zusammengewÃ¼rfelt. Aber es bleibt absolut genialer Nonsense! Die Charaktere hauen einfach mega geile SprÃ¼che raus und die Zwischensequenzen sind einfach zum Totlachen. Dieses Spiel hat einen so geilen Humor, ich bekam beim Spielen einfach feuchte Augen, weil ich ausm Lachen net mehr rauskam.


[b]Grafik/Sound[/b]
Das Spiel wirkt fast, als ob es mit Paint kreiert wurde und genau dieser oberflÃ¤chliche Stil passt wie die Faust aufs Auge. Es wirkt ein wenig wie ein buntes Comic und mit dieser durchgeknallten Geschichte verbunden, ist es absolut passend.
Der Sound schlieÃŸt sich dem problemlos an: Vom dumpfen Aufklatschen bis hin zur sehr geilen Synchronisation!
Sehr hilfreich ist auch, dass wir ein Audiofeedback bekommen, wenn wir einem Gegner wirklich Schaden zufÃ¼gen.
Die Musik hat sich wie das Gameplay auch stÃ¤ndig geÃ¤ndert und es ist fast alles dabei, von elektronischer Begleitmusik zum Metal. Verdammt, selbst Beethovens "FÃ¼r Elise" war dabei, wobei ich da, vom Kontext her. beinahe vor Lachen vom Stuhl gefallen wÃ¤re.


[b]Fazit[/b]
"No Time To Explain" ist eine wahre Indieperle und ich hab dieses Spiel absolut ins Herz geschlossen. Das Gameplay Ã¤ndert sich stÃ¤ndig, wird nicht langweilig und deswegen habe ich das Spiel auch fast am StÃ¼ck durchgespielt. Die Grafik und die Musik sorgen einfach stÃ¤ndig fÃ¼r neue Ãœberraschungen und man hat auch durch die sehr lustige Geschichte immer was zum Lachen. Das Spiel ist einfach ein einziger Witz, aber ein verdammt guter. Ich persÃ¶nlich hatte schon lange kein Spiel mehr, wo ich derart oft lachen musste. AuÃŸerdem wirkt es so wunderbar unverbraucht und frisch, dass mir mal wieder klar wurde, warum ich Indiespiele so liebe. Wer den Trailer gesehen hat, sollte wissen, dass das Spiel noch 10-mal abstruser und lustiger ist. FÃ¼r knapp 3-4 Stunden, Workshop mal ausgenommen, sind 15 â‚¬ nicht wenig. Aber dafÃ¼r kauft man hier jede Menge SpaÃŸ und daher bin ich mir bei dieser Empfehlung so sicher, wie ich es selten bin!



Wenn dir das Review gefallen hat, wÃ¼rde ich mich freuen, wenn du [url=http://steamcommunity.com/groups/Drakeschool] meiner Kuratorgruppe auf Steam [/url]folgst, um auch meine Reviews zu anderen Spielen zu bekommen.

author: {'steamid': '76561198019328070', 'num_games_owned': 470, 'num_reviews': 136, 'playtime_forever': 171, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 171, 'last_played': 1496388043}
review:
I thought this was a pretty fun platformer - it takes some getting used to, but the controls are an interesting variant. Some of the humor was worth a chuckle, some of it didn't quite land. All the levels introduce a new twist on the mechanic, which keeps it interesting. The bosses were all fun to play. My favorite stage was the black & white one where you had to "paint" the walls to see what you were supposed to do - sadly, this stage was followed by the Rejected Clone level, or as I like to refer to it, God's Greatest Mistake.

I got this through Humble Bundle - not sure I would drop 15 bucks for it by itself, but it's a good time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198009236488', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 22, 'playtime_forever': 392, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 392, 'last_played': 1495841458}
review:
'Salright. 

Not 15 euros alright, but 'salright. I'd feel dissatisfied if I didn't get it cheap from a bundle.

Gets frustrating sometimes, cause the controls could have been better. I played it with mouse/kb, so it's not terribly unwieldy, but I imagine playing it with a controller is borderline impossible. and there are several segments where gameplay changes a bit, which wouldn't be a problem as it isn't so complex that you couldn't figure it out, but the controls will feel a bit janky, and I did feel like I was making due with the controls rather than having them as an extention of myself.

There are some mechanics that I'm pretty sure are an exploit the devs overlooked, and not a clever inclusion.
I did have a problem playing it full screen, where you get black stripes on the top and bottom of the screen, because of the resolution of the game, and I wouldn't bring it up, except your cursor can get lost in it, so it's kind of hard to see where you're aiming.

But despite all that, it is a kinda neat platform/puzzler. I just wouldn't get it unless it's 5 euros or cheaper.
I didn't talk about the mechanics of the game, cause figuring them out is part of the fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198313305019', 'num_games_owned': 985, 'num_reviews': 62, 'playtime_forever': 286, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 81, 'last_played': 1574495368}
review:
[spoiler]won this game in giveaway on Steamgifts[/spoiler]

I have not played original [b]No Time To Explain[/b], so I don't know difference between it and remastered version, so I'll just list things that I found good and/or bad in remastered version:

+ First of all, what makes [b]No Time To Explain Remastered[/b] different from other games is it's gameplay style. Besides interesting graphics, you'll find lots of comedy and entertaining things in it, for example - memes in form of hats and voice acting.

- Difficulty of the game, which is mostly caused by small bugs in game, for example - jumping with your laser gun does not always work in a way you want.

At last - would I recommend game to others? - Of course! But not at full price. $15 is a little too much for this game. I would rather buy it on sale or in bundle.

Final score: 7/10.

author: {'steamid': '76561198133565082', 'num_games_owned': 2227, 'num_reviews': 37, 'playtime_forever': 198, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 198, 'last_played': 1495521652}
review: This is an old 2D side scroller that might be called a "precision platformer" if it was released today. Although your character can run and jump, the game is largely based around using your laser beam both to shoot enemies and as a jetpack type thruster. It is difficult to describe how poorly this is implemented. The "jetpack" provides different arbitrary levels of thrust depending on which direction it is pointed and when it's fired. Some reviewers claim that some hidden random number generator controls the output, but that is not true -- the physics are total nonsense but they are the same nonsense every time. Aiming directly at the ground and firing always produces the same strange slo-mo super jump. Aiming to the left or right on the ground always pushes you the opposite direction with no acceration whatsoever. Jumping and firing left or right  sends you hurtling across the screen like scarecrow strapped to a jet engine. Jumping and firing down does basically nothing. Firing right/left and then swinging the thruster down results in nothing: no super jump, even if you are grounded. It makes no sense and feels deeply unsatisfying but it can be learned. Helpfully, the checkpoints come quickly and the game is mercifully over after three hours or so. Sprinkled on top of the central dysfunction are various other mechanics, including a piece of cake that transformes you into a fat bowling ball and a truly  wretched bullet hell sequence. These are mere diversions though -- little more than mini games. The meat of NTTE is imprecise "precision" platforming punctuated by infuriating boss fights. All of this is wrapped in a moldy layer of newgrounds style early internet humor. I hated hated HATED this game. Forget paying, this is just not worth your time.

author: {'steamid': '76561198127331673', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 54, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 20, 'last_played': 1495186359}

author: {'steamid': '76561197968258381', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 33, 'playtime_forever': 124, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 124, 'last_played': 1495479932}
review:
The premise of the game revolves around a terrible control scheme.  The game's defining feature, shooting to move, is a great concept that has been done in games before but this one executes it poorly.  The cursor regularly needs to be aimed off screen and, while the cursor is not trapped by the screen, there's no indicator for where it is being aimed.  Movement also moves the cursor which makes aiming for particular targets very difficult. Spacebar, a key which usualyl means jump, instead does nothing.  Well, it does do something but it's not relevant to movement.  Sometimes levels mix up the control scheme, like the shotgun level or the telekenesis level, but they really feel like explored concepts that were wedged into the game instead of being rightfully discarded.

There's a lot of dying and retrying in this game, which isn't necessarily bad, but the pacing of retries is no where on the level of Super Meat Boy.  Some times dying, like flying off screen in the cake world, takes an extraordinary amount of time.  Sometimes dying resets the whole level, except this triggers the slow fadeout/fadein.  I loved the theme, but the gameplay is too much of a hassle.

author: {'steamid': '76561198146682116', 'num_games_owned': 1052, 'num_reviews': 42, 'playtime_forever': 355, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 187, 'last_played': 1668643796}
review:
I played No Time To Explain when it was just a flash game, all was excellent the voice acting, gameplay and difficulty levels. To me this is a very good game even if most critics from 2017 are negative for it.
I'd recommend at least trying it, it's cheap on every key-selling site and contains what we could expect from an indie game.
It may not be as good as other tinyBuild games but it's the game that made them feel like a real company, their first game.

The music of the Credits is also truly beautiful, nice remix of Triple Gear

author: {'steamid': '76561197982727216', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 115, 'playtime_forever': 16, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 16, 'last_played': 1494809919}
review:
I'm sure this game will appeal to some hardcore platforming fans (especially those who enjoy Super Meat Boy, etc) but it was just too difficult and annoying for me.  Some levels are extremely demanding and hearing the same screaming death cries becomes super irritating.  I know I didn't play for long, but I got so frustrated that I Rage Quit.  (I still haven't fully figured out the first ray gun controls.)  Recommended only if super cheap.  Certainly not at $15.

PROS

+ Cute art style
+ Physics-based puzzle platforming with lots of levels and challenges
+ Different "gun style" platforming sections keeps things fresh

CONS

- Hearing the same death screams are funny at first but quickly become annoying
- Keyboard and mouse controls are confusing and frustrating
- Some levels require split-second timing and precision
- Constant deaths in difficult levels often caused me to Rage Quit

author: {'steamid': '76561198010997388', 'num_games_owned': 831, 'num_reviews': 16, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1494714336}
review:
I got this game a while ago and seeing it pop up in the Humble Bundle made me think this was a good time to revisit it.
Unfortunately, I can't *not* recommend this game enough. I know I haven't played much of it but that's not for lack of trying.

Pros:
Apparently, if you play enough of it, it has a story that's not too bad?

Cons:
- Controls.
The controls are absolutely infuriating. You walk at a snail's pace and the jump is so pitiful that it may as well have been removed from the game. You "jump" about as high as your character is tall which makes it good for literally nothing. All of your movement comes from your weapon.
- Sound.
The music seems to be a poor attempt at a callback to retro games but it's repetetive and grating. It's a fully-voiced game, and on top of the poor sound quality the "jokes" fall flat. All of its humor comes from a "lol so randomz!" standpoint, resulting in a weak chuckle the first time one comes up and an apologetic sigh the following times. In my half hour of play I heard "My insides and my outsides are in pain!" literally 10 times.
- Gameplay.
The biggest issue I have with this is that the gameplay itself just... isn't fun. Sure, it's a difficult platformer, but the difficulty comes from the controls rather than clever design. It has a few ideas that it toys around with for a level or two but never revisits them. It's usually an infinite-life platformer but will then toss you into a boss fight where suddenly lives are a thing. The boss fights are frustrating and give no information on what a boss can or will do until you've already died to it, a problem worsened by the fact that you die while just trying to get into position thanks to the poor controls.

Tl;dr, it's an interesting game that looks far more fun in the trailers than it actually is. The game just isn't worth it to play but looks interesting enough to try. It'd be a dissappointing game if it were $5, but selling this for $15 is insane.

author: {'steamid': '76561198068257137', 'num_games_owned': 336, 'num_reviews': 3, 'playtime_forever': 182, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 126, 'last_played': 1510496195}

author: {'steamid': '76561197988437235', 'num_games_owned': 836, 'num_reviews': 61, 'playtime_forever': 399, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 399, 'last_played': 1494289587}
review:
Product received for free as an update of the old Flash version of the game.

So, there it is: The so called "remastered" edition of No Time To Explain, a game I had been looking forward to since the release of Steam Greenlight - a service that is due to disappear soon! Is the remaster any better? Well - yes! It feels like an actual game now. Is it good? In my opinion: Unfortunately, not really.

The new engine tries to hide the fact that the original was a flash project which tried to be much more than Flash could handle. And it makes the game feel much smoother and precise. However, many flaws weren't improved upon, e.g. the very subpar sound design. Maybe it isn't much a remaster than more a port of a Flash game into a non Flash based engine?

Anyway, as you can see, I did spend my time with this game and went for completion. Much frustration came from the fact that controls now were neither optimized for controller nor keyboard+mouse and to reset a level because of a failed attempt takes awfully long. To switch between control schemes you have to restart the game, the menuing is a mystery... I feel bad for seemingly hating on this game so much but it just seems, the remaster didn't actually fix much of the flaws from the original. It's sad since the game could have been a fun experience. But let's not grieve towards this loss but instead look forward to what lies ahead, I am sure TinyBuild are able to see the flaws themselves (considering the stuff they went through to actually release the game) and improve in their repertoire!

review: I often play games without audio, as my hearing is a little weird. This is never a problem when I play games that aren't story-based, until I found this, I have no idea what is going on without audio. It's random and makes no sense. Subtitles would be helpful, if the characters say anything meaningful at all. The controls are also hard to get at first, and I am glad I got this for free. I would be banging my head against the wall if I spent $15 on this. The game is not interesting. I had hopes for this game, but it's just overhyped and overpriced.

author: {'steamid': '76561198025330870', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 79, 'playtime_forever': 147, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 147, 'last_played': 1493569550}
review: Unresponsive controls in some areas. The main mechanic of the game can be fun when it works as intended, but often times the force feels random. Lots of trial and error to get to the collectables. Restarting repeats mildly amusing(the first time) dialog that gets stale quicker than the game itself does. Recent reviews have it listed as "Mixed" A fair assessment I feel. If the concept strongly interests you I encourage you to wait for a decent sale for it to hit a worth its value price point.

author: {'steamid': '76561198134543787', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 2, 'playtime_forever': 334, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 334, 'last_played': 1493402915}
review:
This is one of those games, that are pretty fun to watch, but awful to play on your own. I really like most things about this game: the art, the humour, the "plot". BUT (and that's a big but) it's really hard and frustrating. And the reason behind that is NOT, that the game itself is difficult, it's just the awful controls that make it hard.
There are games that are challenging and have great controls AND there are games that are frustrating, because they have bad controls. This one is latter.

review:
Pros
-has some interesting mechanics
-decent hardness
-interesting little platformer
-a few funny lines

Cons
-excessive screen shake (just finished the game and I now have a headache)
-many times your gun shoots you away harder or softer then other times which really throws off trajectories
-not clear on how to beat the mechanical mole (had to look up solution)
-story makes no sense (which is why there is no time to explain)

all in all its an ok platformer (if you decide to buy this only get it on a sale)

Edit: I decided to change my review because reflecting on my experience I didn't think this game is as good as what you could spend your time/money on with something else

review: Warning: It's a difficult game. It doesn't seem to have checkpoint between bosses. If you're just in for the comedy like I did, you're better off watching somebody else play this game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198119390591', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 184, 'playtime_forever': 1239, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 1002, 'last_played': 1443909166}
review:
[h1] No Time To Explain Remastered [/h1]
[i] This is a very fun and well made platform game, but it is not one of the easiest to finish but its not too difficult too. The hero of the game is a person who leads a peaceful life until one afternoon falls into it through the wall, he himself from the future. Our goal is to get safely from the beginning of the level to the very end. Here comes the help of a jet rifle that we will use to finish the level and fight bosses. In my opinion it offers a great and intense gameplay, very funny moments, nice soundtrack and graphic. I sincerely recommend it to everyone who did not play it. [/i]

author: {'steamid': '76561198069452666', 'num_games_owned': 427, 'num_reviews': 10, 'playtime_forever': 26, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 26, 'last_played': 1476552082}
review:
At first I thought it was a virus on my pc I just got. Then I downloaded it like I would any other video game, after I ran it i started to think that maybe instead it wasn't a virus but a well thought out program that came to life. 

Anyways, the begginning to the game really caught me off gaurd but as i steadily progressed past the inensive screaming of my future self I realized that its really fun and something to pass the time, before I knew I had played for a good hour. I just couldnt help it, I enjoyed hearing my future self scream for help as I waded through walls and walls of dirt with my amazing energy cannon.

Did I mention there is an energy cannon?

author: {'steamid': '76561198019689967', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 31, 'playtime_forever': 27, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 27, 'last_played': 1567808107}
review:
I played the original flashgame back in the day, and since then have been curious about playing this full game.

No, don't get it. It is just bad. I wouldn't pay $5 for this game, $15 is highway robbery.

Controls don't feel responsive, level design is awful and lazy. The game doesn't even have resolution options.

Edit: I'm also pretty sure the devs are engaging in review manipulation, as the average review has skyrocketed from "Mixed" to "Very Positive" in just the past month.

author: {'steamid': '76561197971930833', 'num_games_owned': 0, 'num_reviews': 28, 'playtime_forever': 131, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 131, 'last_played': 1488037002}
review:
The story is funny but the game is a pot-luck based die-a-lot-hope-you-hit-the-right-bit kinda thing. The variety in items you get to blast your way around each level gives a nice break from the usual platform jumper. Wtih most games like this I tend to feel a sense of achievement as well as frustration but I found completing levels were so based off of luck that I never got the sense of achievement, instead it was about how long I could be bothered to keep trying again and again till it worked.

Bosses were the best bit of the game though. Not worth getting just for that but they were fun.

author: {'steamid': '76561198069092496', 'num_games_owned': 4112, 'num_reviews': 47, 'playtime_forever': 271, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 271, 'last_played': 1487799780}
review:
I Don't understand why this game has so many positive reviews. If you do like this game, feel free to explain it to me in the comments (but know that I can't resond).

I found the controls to be unresponsive and unpredictable. movement without your 'jump gun' is so slow it's pointless, and movement with it is rather odd. For example: If you shoot down whilst on the ground you fly way up into the air, but if you shoot left or right, you nearly don't move at all. If you jump just before using the gun you get no lift at all. 
I found it to be quite frustrating that I never quite knew where I was going to move next, which in a precision platformer like this just feels wrong. I thnk the creator of the game knew this, which is why there are so many checkpoints so close to each other.

The hit detection I also found to be unclear. There seems to be an invisible area around the character that makes it so that you get hit even if your sprite was not. This problem and the problem above make it so that the game, and the bossfights in particular, just feel like trial and error. As if you're never really fully in control and responsible for what happens on-screen.

The story is ok. The time travel trope is funny in the beginning, but just kind of peters out near the middle of the game.

author: {'steamid': '76561198103126309', 'num_games_owned': 577, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 242, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 242, 'last_played': 1487796478}

author: {'steamid': '76561198087604225', 'num_games_owned': 726, 'num_reviews': 7, 'playtime_forever': 44, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 44, 'last_played': 1487532126}
review:
My 45 Minute experience:
     I used to play this game when it was still in browser. I liked it then because it was fun and easy to play. It was also a good way to waste some time. That was years ago though. Now that I've played it again, it seems a lot harder to get the main way of travel to work. It just doesn't feel right and it has it's own temper. It is fun though. just a simple click and move to the portal game, with a few boss fights. The options are very limited, but the only options you would need. I wish I could have turned off the screen shake because that gives me a headache to look at for an extended period of time. 

     Overall it is an okay game. I will go back to it if I need some time to waste, but I'm going to go out of my way to beat it. 5/10

author: {'steamid': '76561198050856670', 'num_games_owned': 363, 'num_reviews': 18, 'playtime_forever': 70, 'playtime_last_two_weeks': 0, 'playtime_at_review': 70, 'last_played': 1487515064}
review:
I was actually a bit upset when I finally got around to playing this game. Everything I heard about it was positive. The controls were new and inventive, it was humorous, the level design was great. But the more I played it, the more stuff I found that I really did not like at all.

The controls are awful. You use WSAD to move and jump, and the spacebar makes you dance, because I suppose the devs thought the 2 second dance from the beginning of the game was hilarious enough to throw into the control scheme. Dancing is like a taunt in fighting games. It doesnt do anything. You then use the mouse to guide the giant laser that you shoot. Only your cursor also moves with your character. Not with the screen, your character. If you move left, the cursor moves left. WHO THOUGHT THAT WOULD BE A GOOD IDEA? It makes the physics-based puzzles so much harder than they actually are. But aside from the controls, there were a lot of other things I started questioning.

-Why is the game locked to 720p? It just makes it look dated and confined.
-Why are the alternate weapons just used as gimmicks for specific puzzles?
-If the devs opted to include voice acting, why dont their mouths move?
-Why do I have infinite lives for the entire game, but only 3 for boss fights?
-Why are the boss fights the only actual enemies in the game?
-Why doesnt the level selection have any info on the level you are playing? I cant even tell which one I left off on when I go back to play the game.

Then there is the game's "humor" if I can even call it that. This game has 2 jokes throughout the entire game. The first is the rampant screaming you hear your future self yell in the first few levels, which jus gets annoying when you realize the devs only recorded about 12 phrases that just get looped over and over again. The second joke comes directly from the title, and what I mean by that is they dont explain anything and just expect you to find it humorous and accept it, which I dont. WHY IS a giant crab trying to kill me? WHY IS there a random UFO? WHY IS there a giant groundhog with a drill in its mouth as a boss? If you didnt want to explain anything, why make so much stuff that needs explaining? Random does not equal funny.

On a final note, the game is not terrible, but it has enough problems to a point where it feels like a beta. I expected more from a "remastered" game. That being said, the game's strong point is the levels. Playing through them was fun, and if it was just that it would be an awesome arcade-style game. But with the immense number of bad things I found in the game, I can not recommend it.
